title: Column | Touch grass, try a tailgate
author: Julia Kushner | The Daily Collegian
description:
A beloved preparatory ritual signifying unity and controlled transgression, tailgating is so much more than a bunch of silly geese drinking their little faces off.

There’s nothing more American than college football. And there’s definitely nothing more American than a Ford F-150, burgers and dogs and an ice-cold beer on top of college football.

Tailgating is an essential part of game day. We wake up early, dress in our finest blue and white, and break all social barriers.

The usual group dynamics are totally shaken up — parents, students and alumni alike party together and celebrate their shared heritage (if you will) of Penn State ball. We come together, not as different sects of the social strata, but as a singular group with a shared interest.

It’s a lax way to socialize with both peers and adults, as you’ll inevitably end up with someone’s mother and father, their siblings and maybe even their grandparents. It’s an easy way to flex those social muscles in a setting that eliminates all awkwardness by breaching the normal rules of traditional etiquette.

As a Southerner, meeting an adult, I will still say “yes ma’am” or “no sir,” but the hesitancy of chatting with people typically above your social paygrade all but evaporates.

And so many people have this “the more the merrier” attitude. Strike up a conversation with the tailgate next to yours, and you’ll be partying with people you met five seconds ago before you know it.

Compare this with the usual attitude of more formal invitations and the Gen Z inability to even smile at your neighbors in the hallways.

And we transgress other norms as well. My freshman year, before we sold alcoholic beverages at Beaver Stadium, all of Penn State was a dry campus.

That is, except for game days. It was this unspoken rule that you better not be caught dead with liquor in 16802 — unless it was a fall Saturday, of course.

I used to love seeing 18-year-olds traipsing along Millennium Science Complex with a couple of twelve packs in their hands and the police just a hundred yards or so off pretending not to notice.

And music is played so loudly, you’d think your eardrums would burst and the police’d come knocking down your door for a noise complaint, but it’s par for the course in the fields above the stadium.

America prizes the individual, rightly so, but gamedays let us put our group above ourselves, if just for a couple of fun-filled hours. Tailgating and rooting for a team allow us to prioritize something besides our own little worlds for a change.

How nice it is to forget ourselves for a moment to watch Nick Singleton absolutely dominate with 107,000 of your closest friends.

People are able to forget about themselves and what they look like and who they’re with for the duration of the day. They’re able to loosen the death grip social media typically has on young people’s everyday lives and live in the moment while they finally touch some grass.

And there’s so much symbology. Flags fly everywhere from the stars and bars to the Nittany Lion, from fraternity letters to Nicki Minaj. Next time you find yourself at a tailgate, stop for just a moment and appreciate the camaraderie that college has afforded us.

MORE COLUMNS

title: Weekly Recap | No. 4 women’s hockey completes season sweep over Robert Morris
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
To complete a four-game home stand, No. 4 Penn State took its talents outdoors to Beaver Stadium for the first-ever outdoor hockey game in program history.

The Nittany Lions won 3-0 in Friday’s outdoor game and 5-2 on Saturday when the team returned to Pegula Ice Arena.

With its sweep this weekend over Robert Morris, Penn State took the regular-season series against the Colonials 4-0, with goaltender Katie DeSa recording shutouts in three of the four contests. The blue and white outscored the Colonials 16-2 over the season.

Penn State has now completed regular season sweeps over three conference opponents: Robert Morris, Delaware and Syracuse. It’ll have a chance to add two more teams to that running list as it concludes the season with games against Lindenwood and RIT.

Following this past weekend’s action, Penn State is now 26-4 overall, 19-1 in conference play and has won each of its last seven games. It also maintained its perfect 13-0 home record.

Outwater on top

Scoring two goals and assisting on two others against Roberts Morris this weekend was Grace Outwater.

The sophomore winger’s four points were the most among the team. It’s the second time she’s scored four points in two games this season, having done so against Syracuse in November.

Outwater found the back of the net on the power play in the second period to cut the Colonials’ lead from two goals to one. It was her 20th goal of the season, which put her above Tessa Janecke, who’s out for the Olympics, for the most in the AHA.

The Picton, Ontario, native has scored in each of her last seven games, going back to a 4-1 win on Jan. 16 over Syracuse.

Walsh’s weekend

Just over halfway through the second period in Friday’s matchup, McKenna Walsh opened the scoring, giving her the first Division I goal in Beaver Stadium. It ended her drought of 14 games without a goal.

Walsh followed up her history-making performance on Friday with another goal on Saturday to put the Nittany Lions up 3-2, giving her the game-winning goal in both games, the first two of her career.

It’s the first time she has scored in back-to-back contests in her two seasons with the blue and white.

Butze in the books

Danica Maynard scored on the power play in the second period to put Penn State up 4-2 on Saturday. With her assist on the goal, Kendall Butze passed Lyndie Lobdell for most career points by a defenseman in Penn State hockey history with the 85th point of her career.

Butze added to her numbers with an assist on a Katelyn Roberts goal to give her 86 career points.

This season, the Cleveland, Ohio, native totaled four goals and 21 assists for 25 points in 30 games played.

Six scorers

The blue and white spread the scoring love over the weekend with six different skaters finding the back of the net.

Walsh and Outwater scored in both contests, as Roberts, Maynard, Maddy Christian and Abby Stonehouse also scored a goal. Roberts inched closer and closer to the century mark after her goal served as the 95th point of her career.

Admirable attendance

Despite the below-freezing temperatures, a record-breaking number of fans braved the cold to show their support for the Nittany Lions.

With an announced attendance of 1,838 people, Penn State set a new record for the most-attended home game in program history.

The Nittany Lions will continue to wind down their regular season in Missouri when they face the Lindenwood Lions. Game 1 is scheduled at 5 p.m. Friday.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Olympic preview | Nicole Hall, Jessica Adolfsson, Team Sweden’s path to the gold medal game
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s an Olympic year. Like every other country headed to the Milan Cortina Olympic Games, Team Sweden, with current Nittany Lion, Nicole Hall and former Penn Stater Jessica Adolfsson have a chance to take home the gold.

Taking home an Olympic gold medal is one of the oldest sporting honors, but getting there is an accomplishment of its own. Sweden is a powerhouse in the hockey world, and the women's team, commonly known in Sweden as the “Damkronorna” or “The Lady Crowns,” always held its own. Team Sweden has two medals under its belt; here are the steps it needs to take to secure gold number three.

Step One: Preliminary Rounds

Team Sweden will face Germany on Feb. 5, Italy on Feb. 7, France on Feb. 8 and Japan on Feb. 10. Depending on the results of those games, Team Sweden will advance to playoff matches in hopes of reaching the gold medal match.

Team Sweden is looking at redemption this year after a less-than-ideal finish at the 2022 Beijing Olympics, finishing eighth, which is its lowest to date. Historically, it has had a pretty decent run at the Olympics, being a powerhouse among the other teams, so a comeback could very much be in their cards.

Looking at the teams it will face, Team Germany and France are returning to the Olympic Games after some time away. Team Germany could struggle against Sweden, as this is its first Olympic appearance since 2014. Team France is making its Olympic debut this year, so taking on an established team like Sweden could be a challenge. Team Italy, featuring Nittany Lion Matilde Fantin, is returning to the games after 20 years. The most accomplished opponent Team Sweden faces in the group stages is Team Japan, which finished ahead of the Swedes at the 2022 Beijing Olympics in fifth place, so that matchup will be one to watch.

Step 2: Quarter Finals

As of now, there is no guarantee of what the four quarterfinal games will look like, but the pool of teams to choose from is strong. There are powerhouses: Team USA, Team Canada, Team Switzerland and Team Finland, against whom the remaining teams, such as Team Sweden, will have to compete.

These matchups will be quality, with every team bringing in new talent and new ideas. Team Sweden, which features young collegiate talent, may consider a new approach in these tournament stage rounds.

Team Sweden went down in the quarter finals at the 2022 Beijing Olympics, taking a brutal loss from Team Canada, 11-0. Faceoffs were a major struggle for the Swedes, who lost the majority. Confidence can carry them through the group stages and may be the reason they reach the semi-finals.

Step 3: Semi-Finals

Team Sweden has had major success in the semi-finals; the most memorable is the major upset against Team USA at the 2006 Turin Olympics, in which the team beat the Americans in a shoot out.

Team Sweden won one of their two medals at the Turin Olympics, securing silver and leaving the Americans with bronze. Reaching medal contention will be a journey, especially for a team focused on rebuilding as much as Team Sweden.

Step 4: Finals

Reaching medal contention will likely mean getting past Team Switzerland or Team Finland and, most likely, facing Team USA or Canada. The Swedish have the history, the talent and the fire. The Nittany Lions already have multiple Olympians and Olympic medalists, and Team Sweden has the potential to increase that number.

MORE OLYMPICS CONTENT

title: ‘This is real’ | Penn State alum Dan Barefoot set to represent Team USA in skeleton
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State will be represented by several athletes in this month’s Olympic Winter Games, but few of them have a story quite as interesting as Dan Barefoot, who will be competing in skeleton, a winter sledding sport, for Team USA.

Barefoot grew up in nearby Johnstown, Pennsylvania, and attended Richland High School.

He graduated from the university in 2013 with a degree in landscape architecture. The rigor of his academics was a key force in his desire to pursue athletics after graduation.

“I probably spent like six hours a day just working in the studio in the architecture school,” Barefoot said. “There was never a moment in my day where I wasn’t doing something, and I think I got used to that. I liked staying busy, and I think that was the reason I attempted to look up the sport.”

It’s hard enough to become an Olympic athlete, let alone in a sport that most Americans haven’t even heard of. The 35-year-old credits his discovery of the unique event to a simple internet search.

“I literally just started Googling things,” Barefoot said. “That’s how I came across the sport. Alphabetically, bobsled and skeleton were near the top, and it was one of the first things I clicked on.”

While he came across the sport in an instant, the journey to its highest level hasn’t been equally as quick for Barefoot. He’s been competing for nearly a decade, this year marking his ninth year involved with the sport, and it’s been a grind to get to where he is.

Like many sports, there are several levels of competition that an athlete has to work up in order to reach the peak.

“The system is set up kind of like Major League Baseball,” Barefoot said. “The World Cup is the MLB, and there’s all these layers under it. You try your best in the lower levels, and once in a while, you get a podium spot. Then the federation moves you up to the next level, and you suck again, but eventually you get another podium spot and they move you up again.”

Barefoot spent those years working his way up the ranks until he made his first World Cup team about three and a half years ago. As the highest level of skeleton, outside of the Olympics, it was the toughest test yet for the 5-foot-10 athlete.

“It’s a dogfight up there,” Barefoot said. “I was getting my a— kicked in a couple races, but I also had a couple races that were good. At the end of the day, it’s a total points thing, so you can have a couple bad races, but if you have a couple good races, you get points for those.”

With skeleton being such a niche sport, at least on the national stage, Barefoot works as a landscape architect in addition to competing. Balancing work, training and competing became difficult as he began taking it more seriously.

“In the beginning, I was a landscape architect, and this was a thing that I was trying,” Barefoot said. “That thing that I was trying became more serious, and over time, I was putting more and more effort into the sport and working less and less.”

Ultimately, Barefoot and his superiors decided to transfer him to a part-time employee, so he could continue to pursue skeleton, and that change has worked well for both parties, so far. These games will be Barefoot’s first, and surprisingly, he initially wasn’t as excited to qualify as many would expect.

“I had no emotions,” Barefoot said. “You get so focused along the way on the small goals, like if you were driving and looking right in front of your headlights instead of down the road, and that’s the way you make progress. But then, all of a sudden, you get to your destination and you’re like ‘holy s—.’”

He ended up feeling the expected emotion when he told the people who helped him get there.

“It really wasn’t until I was texting my mom and responding to Instagram messages from friends that I had before I started the sport, guys whose couch I was sitting on, saying ‘I’m trying out for this sport,’ and they would say ‘keep at it, let’s see what happens.’ When I was messaging those guys back, all of a sudden tears started coming to my eyes, and I was like, ‘holy s—, this is real.’ Because it’s not just a journey for me. So many people have been involved.”

Skeleton is unique because of the high speeds and relatively little control the athletes have. Those factors give beginners huge adrenaline rushes, but Barefoot has grown to find peace in the uncontrollable.

“Once you fully commit to something that you know you can't back out from, metaphorically or literally, your body becomes so calm,” Barefoot said. “It locks in. All the noise that would be floating around in your head goes away.”

Despite Barefoot finding it peaceful, skeleton is undoubtedly dangerous. He had a recent run-in with a track worker that will sideline him for his first opportunity to get on the ice in Italy, but it shouldn’t have an effect in competition.

“This guy was watching the camera feed,” Barefoot said. “Expecting to see when I would start sliding, but it stopped working, and he never saw that happen. As soon as I came out of a corner, and looked up to look at the next one, I saw two legs and a shovel.”

The impact caused a tear in his deltoid, which isn’t ideal as he enters the games, but is far better than a joint or bone injury. Those injuries could have prevented an opportunity that Barefoot and those around him had been working towards for years.

“My support team, I feel like, was more important than me,” Barefoot said. “In this journey, I feel like I contributed like a third of it, and the other two-thirds is everybody supporting, sharing stories and donating. Without those pieces, I’m not here. I’m looking forward to representing them, feeling excited, and feeling grateful to potentially do a once-in-a-lifetime thing.”

It’s been a journey to get to the games for Barefoot, and he’ll finally get a chance to race on the sport’s biggest stage on Feb.12 and 13. Even though the pressure is on, he’s staying grounded as the days approach.

“Thinking about getting a medal at the Olympics doesn’t get you a medal at the Olympics,” Barefoot said. “What gets you a medal is thinking about the form, the breathing, the small stuff. My goal is to keep it simple, to really relax, enjoy the moment, trust everything that I’ve put in so far, and really lean on that.”

title: Column | All it takes is a few chicken nuggets
author: Daniela White | The Daily Collegian
description:
Like any young adult in college, I've been trying to convince myself for years that I won’t get homesick. For me, living in Maryland and going to Penn State, only three hours away, I never really had to worry about it too much. All it takes is a phone call from my parents and they'll come get me or I’ll make the drive home.

Now, my home for the next four months is in Barcelona, Spain, 4,000 miles away instead of just under 200 miles. I’ve switched from English to Spanish, use the Barcelona Metro instead of the “WHOOP,” and traded sweat pants for jeans from Zara.

When I first got here, I thought to myself, “I’ll be so busy, I won’t even have time to get homesick.” And I was right, at the beginning.

My second weekend here, I hopped on a plane to the Scottish Highlands. I spent two days off the coast of Spain, only an hour from Barcelona. My week was booked and busy with clubs, cafes, and repeat. I didn’t have time to get homesick. Then, I had my weekly FaceTime with my family and my mom was cruel enough to ask if I missed her.

Once she asked that single question I would get lost in my thoughts to and from class.

I would get quiet at night, knowing their sun was still shining while I was stuck with the moon. I missed them terribly.

Knowing myself, however, I knew I would drive myself crazy if I kept myself in that homesick funk, so I turned to my constants. Fast food and TV dramas.

While I grieve the absence of Chipotle and Chick-fil-a, and I can no longer hop into my car and drive through Happy Valley, I found other avenues. I turned away from the one euro tacos for a meal at KFC and McDonald's.

I finally figured out how to change the Spanish audio to English on my TV in my apartment and scrolled for hours on Hulu, watching episode after episode of cringey American shows.

When I caught a cold, I sacrificed a class absence to journey to the 24-hour markets and scour for a pack of Oreo’s and Diet Coke (or Coca-Cola Zero as they say here) and watched movies snuggled up in my bed, imagining I was back at home or in my apartment in State College.

I did anything that reminded me of being in Maryland or Penn State, keeping myself tethered to my old self while I became a new person at the same time. I worked around the time differences and reached out to my roommates back home and other friends abroad, keeping my relationships alive and constant.

I reminded myself that my life would still be there when I returned, and I reminded myself that being abroad was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

Almost a month now, I have special routines. I allow myself to eat fast food once or twice a week. I’ll have a Pink Drink from Starbucks instead of a café con leche.

While there’s so much to be seen in Barcelona, and so many new things to throw and immerse myself into, it’s important to have a balance. Give yourself some time to FaceTime your parents, or watch a Netflix movie with your roommates abroad, just to get a little taste of what’s waiting for you back at home.

MORE ABROAD COLUMNS

title: 5 ways to create the perfect Galentine's Day party
author: Ava Krysko | The Daily Collegian
description:
Not to be cliché, but most people know love comes in many forms, and doesn't always necessarily mean the relationship between a couple. Many out there may scramble to get reservations at a favorite restaurant and buy a perfect Valentine's Day gift — some may even stress about getting a date — but Feb. 14 doesn't have to be that way.

You can always celebrate the day with friends, who, let's be honest, may be the group of people you love the most. After all, why limit a fabulous holiday filled with candy, affection and hearts to romantic relationships?

Galentine's Day is meant to show love to the gal pals and bros in your life. There are so many ways to have a fun Galentine's Day party, and here are five to ensure a great time with your besties.

1) Decorate

Any proper party thrower knows that decorations are what set the mood for a get together. Boring decorations equal a boring party. Although Valentine's Day decor might not be as easy to find as other major holidays such as Christmas and Halloween, there's still plenty to choose from at stores such as Target and Michaels.

If you're on a budget for Galentine's, there's no need to worry, decorating doesn't have to be expensive. With plenty of homemade options that look just as cute, the sky's the limit.

For example, heart garlands made of red and pink construction paper or felt are perfect for stunning guests. Another option is painting wine glasses with cute Valentine's designs. Not only does this make for an adorable decoration, but also it provides drinkware.

If you doubt your crafting abilities, or simply don't want to take on crafting by yourself, you can always rope in your friends to craft decorations at the party, adding an activity. This can be especially fitting if you're celebrating Galentine's with your roommates.

2) Provide food and drinks

Possibly the best part of any party is the food. Pizza and hoagies are a classic you may want to serve, or you can go for something a bit more niche like your favorite restaurant or something you've never tried before.

Candy salads or charcuterie boards make for perfect appetizers and are aesthetically pleasing as well.

When it comes to drinks for Galentine's Day, any pink or red punch or mocktail will do the trick. You can consider making strawberry daiquiris or alcoholic shirley temples for those over 21, and edible glitter can be added to any of these options to make them shine even more.

3) Bake a sweet treat

If there's any day that's meant for a sweet treat, it's Galentine's Day. There's endless options for dessert, but anything strawberry or cherry-flavored fits the theme the best. This can include strawberry shortcake, cherry tarts or even chocolate-covered strawberries.

Baking is especially perfect for Galentine's because it's a practice that uses time and love. Whether you're doing it before the party, or creating a delicacy with your friends, baking takes a lot of heart.

4) Watch a rom-com

Although it can sometimes take suspension of reality to get into a rom-com (what are the odds you bump into a stranger that just happens to be your perfect match?) when it comes to Galentine's, rom-coms are a perfect way to spend the day.

Curling up on the couch with your best friends to gush over a sweet romance can't be beat. Moreover, rom-coms have a certain light-hearted tone that's the best for a day like Galentine's.

If rom-coms really aren't your thing, any type of movie can theoretically work. Even horror/slasher movies could possibly be romantic. After all, nothing quite says "I love you" like the terror of a serial killer.

5) Play a game

To ensure that your partygoers don't get bored, adding a game to the festivities never hurts. This can include things such as Valentine's-themed bingo or trivia.

Another idea is to have each member of your party create different slideshows to present about various topics. The subjects don't have to be boring — curating the perfect skincare routine or ex-partner horror stories can make for an interesting presentation.

Although this may fall a bit into the baking category, creating a "Hear Me Out Cake" may provide some entertainment as well. To do this, you'll need a cake, along with pictures of some unconventional people (or characters, there's no judgment here) you find attractive. Each person takes turns revealing their choices and sticking them onto the cake.

Hopefully, these tips will help you create a fun, festive Galentine's Day party with love all around.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: 8 must-reads for Black History Month
author: Ava Krysko | The Daily Collegian
description:
Although it’s often overlooked, reading is one of the best ways to gain information, especially when learning about a different culture. When it comes to Black History Month, picking up a book can help you become a more informed and aware individual.

Whether you decide to pick up a historical fiction novel or an autobiography, reading can help you to explore things you never knew before. To get a better understanding about which books might be helpful, Penn State professors shared eight book recommendations for Black History Month.

1) "The African Origin of Civilization: Myth or Reality" by Cheikh Anta Diop

First published in 1974, this book presents historical and archaeological information to assert ancient Egyptian civilization was founded by Africans. Although white Egyptologists tried to debunk his theory, Diop argued fiercely that it was correct.

This book was recommended by Michael West, professor of African American studies, history and African studies, because he said it is "foundational for understanding global African history."

2) "Black Reconstruction" by W.E.B. Du Bois

Written by renowned author, W.E.B. Du Bois, "Black Reconstruction" tells the story of African Americans during the Reconstruction Era. It explores the ways in which Black Americans reshaped democracy and reconstructed America post-Civil War.

Also recommended by West, he said it's an important read because of "its exposition of the Black agency in the single most important event in U.S. experience."

3) "The Black Book" edited and compiled by Toni Morrison

"The Black Book," published in 1974, reads like an anthology. It contains stories and historical documents of African Americans from the beginning of slavery to the mid-20th century in America.

According to Professor Carmin Wong, a graduate research assistant who recommended the book, "The Black Book” serves as a visual and documentary archive of Black history in the United States, as it uses photographs, ephemera and historical records to center Black life and cultural memory.

Additionally, Wong said Morrison makes Black history accessible for wider audiences.

"Morrison was acutely aware of readership, who these stories are written for, who has access to them and who has been excluded," Wong said. “‘The Black Book’ reflects this awareness with compilations of historical records in a way that invites engagement from readers who may not otherwise encounter Black history in institutional archives or academic texts."

4) "How Europe Underdeveloped Africa" by Walter Rodney

This book takes a look at how Europe exploited Africa's resources for themselves and created overwhelming issues when it comes to the continent’s progress in politics, society and the economy.

Wong also recommended this book and described it as, "a critical examination of colonialism and its long-term economic and social effects on the African continent and African diasporic peoples."

“Rodney argues that the exploitation of Africa led to the underdevelopment and restructuring of pre-colonial African societies, directly challenging narratives that frame colonial rule as beneficial,” Wong said.

Additionally, Wong described how the book takes a look at how colonialism reshaped racial identities of African people and how it left a lasting legacy of global inequality through structured systems of race, power and capitalism.

"I selected this text because I want to be mindful that we need to turn to Black writers across the globe in discourse on Black history, and Rodney's work provides an essential transnational framework that situates African histories and diasporic experiences as central rather than peripheral to these conversations," Wong said.

Wong said while this book is a good starting place to learn more about these ideas and understand the function of class in oppressive systems, it should still be followed up by other texts for further education.

5) "The Third Reconstruction: America's Struggle for Racial Justice in the 21st Century" by Peniel E. Joseph

"The Third Reconstruction," published in 2022, explores the idea that the racial reckoning of 2020 was the climax of the third Reconstruction period in America.

Darryl Thomas, professor of African American studies, recommended this book and said it compares the first two Reconstruction periods — along with the backlash that followed them — and how Black freedom was fostered through the end of current racial regimes.

"Joseph brings attention to the current backlash to the election of Barack Obama as a backlash against diversity, equity and Black freedom," Thomas said.

6) "Making All Black Lives Matter: Reimagining Freedom in the 21st Century" by Barbara Ransby

Another book recommended by Thomas, "Making All Black Lives Matter" focuses on the role of Black feminists in Black liberation movements.

"She (Ransby) pays special attention to the radical Black feminist and others outside of the American establishment who not only challenge mass incarceration but the marginalization of those outside of the mainstream," Thomas said. "She declares that freedom and democracy are a lifestyle as well as human rights for all."

7) "Stamped from the Beginning" by Ibram X. Kendi

Published in 2016, "Stamped from the Beginning" centers on the history of racist ideas and how they infiltrated American society.

Professor and Co-Director of the Center for Black Digital Research Christopher Dancy recommended this book and said it "details a useful history as one considers anti-Blackness in the context of U.S. history and present."

8) "Freedom Dreams" by Robin D.G. Kelley

"Freedom Dreams" chronicles a history of radical Black activism in the United States.

Dancy also recommended this book, and suggests everyone read the most recent edition which includes Kelley's reflections in modern times.

"It's a great book for contextualizing Black experiences within histories of the Black radical tradition," Dancy said.

title: Big Ten recap | Women’s basketball tournament draws closer amidst many upsets
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Big Ten postseason race has tightened with just over a month until the tournament, with four teams clinching their spots in Indianapolis.

In addition to the tournament clinchers, there has been significant action across the conference, including losing streaks by top-25 teams and the first conference win for a bottom-feeder.

Washington, Oregon upset Maryland

At the beginning of January, Maryland was ranked No. 7 before going on a 3-4 run. Entering last week, the Terrapins were ranked No. 16; this week’s AP rankings have them ranked No. 22.

Things haven’t been going well for Maryland, losing another pair of games last week.

After being up by 12 points entering the second half, the Terrapins gave up a 23-point third quarter to Washington. The Huskies took the game to overtime and Maryland ultimately gave up 24 points in a double-overtime window despite Yarden Garzon’s 24 points.

On Saturday, Maryland allowed 24 points in the fourth quarter to Oregon to lose its fourth-straight game and fall to 5-6 in conference play.

Indiana earns 1st conference win

While Garzon’s team hit the losing column again last week, her former team found its first win since Dec. 21.

The Hoosiers came out victorious against Northwestern on Sunday, winning 89-75 for their first conference win of the year.

Former Penn State senior Shay Ciezki continued to make her case as a future WNBA player, recording 33 points for her sixth 30-point game of the year.

Northwestern had two conference wins against Rutgers and Wisconsin heading into Sunday’s game, but fell to the 15th seed in the tournament, teetering on the brink of elimination.

USC, Illinois earn much-needed upsets

After only winning one game in the first three weeks of January, USC ended the month with a big win over then-No. 8 Iowa.

The Hawkeyes had an eight-game winning streak entering Thursday’s contest, but 20-plus point games by Jazzy Davidson and Kara Dunn gave the Trojans the 12-point victory.

Illinois earned an upset of its own, taking down the No. 25 Huskies at home.

The Fighting Illini also had a pair of 20-plus point scorers in Cearah Parchment and Berry Wallace, with Parchment recording a 23-point, 10-rebound double-double.

Battle of Michigan in OT

One of the closest games of the week came in a battle of Michigan as the Wolverines traveled to East Lansing to face Michigan State on Sunday.

It was a close contest between the two teams, as the Wolverines entered the half leading by one point.Both teams were in the top-25 entering the night, but it was No. 9 Michigan who came away victorious.

The Wolverines were led by Mila Holloway and Olivia Olson, who combined for 49 points on the day.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Big Ten roundup | Weekend action sees major upset, transfer portal entrance
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
While Penn State was taking down Nebraska in the Bryce Jordan Center, other conference competition occurred with some major headlines.

Ohio State maintained their undefeated season, setting up a likely unbeaten vs. unbeaten in the Bryce Jordan Center on Feb. 13. A major home upset took place in Minnesota while another conference foe earned its first win.

Ohio State stays undefeated

Ohio State defeated No. 17 Wisconsin and No. 10 Michigan in a two-dual weekend. The Buckeyes won 30-10 and 26-16, respectively, moving to 16-0 on the season.

The Buckeyes were trailing the Badgers 10-9 at the intermission, causing some major questions, but that was without their top 125-pound wrestler.

Nic Bouzakis has been alternating starts if Ohio State wrestles twice in a weekend, causing him to not wrestle against the Badgers. Wisconsin’s Nicolar Rivera won the match at 125 pounds after Vinceng Kilkeary filled in for Bouzakis.

The other headliner was the final bout between Michigan and Ohio State. No. 7 Taye Ghadiali of Michigan and No. 3 Nick Feldman went to sudden victory, where Ghadiali took down Feldman to get the upset victory. It didn’t matter for the dual, but with the postseason around the corner, Ghadiali could improve his seeding in the Big Ten and NCAA Tournament.

Minnesota upsets Iowa

No. 9 Minnesota went into Carver-Hawkeye Arena and took down No. 4 Iowa in a close battle. The Golden Gophers defeated the Hawkeyes, 21-16, on the road behind some headlining victories.

Max McEnelly didn’t have to face Angelo Ferrari, but was still tested at 184 pounds. Gabe Arnold stepped in and performed well, not allowing a takedown through seven minutes of action. With eight seconds remaining in sudden victory, McEnelly took down Arnold to get the victory, 4-1.

With Ferrari’s status still unknown, Arnold appears to be a proven wrestler who can compete with the top, but it was McEnelly who was the better wrestler, expanding the lead to 15-13.

At 157 pounds, Minnesota’s Charlie Millard, ranked No. 21, defeated No. 12 Jordan Williams by major decision. Williams was the favorite entering the match, but Millard put that to rest quickly, defeating Williams 13-3.

Michigan State earns first conference win

Two of the bottom teams in the conference, Michigan State and Northwestern, battled it out in East Lansing, Michigan. The Spartans earned their first win of the season, defeating the Wildcats, 22-20.

It was a late push from Northwestern, as the dual began at 197 pounds. With Michigan State holding a 22-9 lead after the 157-pound weight class, the Wildcats picked things up.

They needed at least a tech fall and two-major decisions, to get to the 22-point mark. Eddie Enright did his job at 174 pounds for Northwestern, winning by major decision, but the 165 pound and 184-pound class ended in decisions, giving Michigan State its first Big Ten dual win of the season.

Massoma Endene

Massoma Endene has been in the headlines for weeks. After being dismissed by Iowa in early January, it’s reported by Justin Basch that Endene will enter the transfer portal and file for a medical redshirt.

With not wrestling since November, Endene’s redshirt will likely go through giving him the chance to compete at the Division I level once again. He won a trio of Division III national championships at Wartburg College before transferring to Iowa. He was removed from the Hawkeyes’ roster and will instantly become a major target for teams with or without a major need at 197 pounds.

Endene was ranked well into the top 10 before being removed from the program, and had some hype to be the biggest test for the current No. 1 at the weight class, Josh Barr.

title: Penn State men's volleyball stays at No. 14 in AVCA Poll
author: Keira Albert | The Daily Collegian

After this week's AVCA Poll, Penn State remains at No. 14.

Still at 1⃣4⃣ in the @AVCAVolleyball Poll#WeAre pic.twitter.com/k6WF4VF4Ha— Penn State Men's Volleyball (@PennStateMVBALL) February 3, 2026

title: Preview | Penn State women’s basketball looks for 1st conference win over Purdue
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is one loss away from tying its second-worst losing streak in program history and has a chance to stop that this week.

The Lady Lions travel to Indiana to face Purdue at 7:00 p.m. Wednesday with just over a month left of the regular season.

With Penn State needing at least two wins to clinch the Big Ten tournament, here’s a look at the first game down the must-win stretch.

Matchup history

Despite Purdue being an inferior team over the past several years, the Lady Lions have an all-time losing record against the Boilermakers.

Penn State is 25-36 in its matchup history, dating back to 1988.

Over the past 10 years, that losing streak is also prevalent, with the blue and white falling 6-8.

Last year’s matchup

The Boilermakers won their first matchup in two years against Penn State last February, coming into the Bryce Jordan Center on Senior Day and winning 92-85.

After entering the second quarter up just one point, Purdue dominated the second period. The Boilermakers ultimately finished the first half up 11 points and held that lead the rest of the game.

Purdue was led by Rashunda Jones and Sophie Swanson, who combined for 61 points. However, Jones left for Michigan State and Swanson for Virginia Tech during the offseason, so Purdue has been left to find a new leading scorer.

The Lady Lions were also led by Gabby Elliott and Grace Hall, who now play for Arizona State and SMU. The duo scored 32 points and 16 points, respectively.

Current redshirt junior Gracie Merkle also scored double-digits against Purdue, recording 10 points, six rebounds and two blocks.

Scouting Purdue

Despite a rough start to the season with a loss to satellite campus Purdue Fort Wayne, the Boilermakers have since recovered and are tentatively in the Big Ten Tournament.

Purdue earned three conference wins in January, beginning with an eight-point victory over Wisconsin. That win then fueled the Boilermakers to an overtime upset of then-No. 23 Washington.

The Lady Lions have since lost to both teams, falling to the Huskies by 16 points on their West Coast trip.

This year’s Purdue squad is a lower-scoring team, averaging only 69.7 points per game. However, all 12 of its athletes have consistently contributed to its scoring and the team has had nine different starters this year.

Redshirt junior Tara Daye leads the Boilermakers with 12.6 points per game after transferring from St. John’s. Junior Kiki Smith has also been a high-scorer, averaging 10.2 points per game after her year at Arkansas.

Purdue’s solid starters will be tested when high-scoring Kiyomi McMiller, Moriah Murray and Merkle come to town on Wednesday.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Weekly recap | Penn State men’s basketball shows flashes despite handicaps
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Well, it’s been a while since a recap on Penn State men’s basketball was released, and it’s fair to say a recap is needed.

The last published recap was in mid-January, and it appeared the Nittany Lions had a chance to turn a corner after a three-game losing skid against ranked opponents to start the new year.

Yet, since that stretch, the blue and white dropped five straight until it finally got back into the win column, and the need to reflect is at a peak. Now, 1-10 in the Big Ten and 10-12 overall, the blue and white have a chance to not only finish on a strong note, but with some momentum for the future.

Really, now?

The play on the court hasn’t been ideal over the last couple of weeks, and the personnel available haven’t been consistent either. Top scorers Freddie Dilione V and Kayden Mingo endured light nicks that affected their play, while all three international big men, Sasǎ Ciani, Ivan Jurić, and Tibor Mirtić, all missed action due to various reasons.

The injuries fractured morale and the quality of play, which hadn’t been high over the end of January and into February. With conference play in its full swing, it’s a disastrous time to see high-profile absences and to endure those devastating losses at the same time. For a young squad that didn’t earn its first Big Ten win until a last-second Mingo buzzer-beater over Minnesota, the emotions within the team are extremely volatile, and fate hasn’t necessarily been the kindest.

Moving forward, a unit that has endured small setbacks at potentially the worst times has a chance to show that those unforeseen circumstances are why the season did not go well, rather than because of the player’s limited ceiling.

Rewarding Reed

As the results haven’t been good, neither have the players' performances. The one silver lining over the past few weeks of play is the emergence of Josh Reed as a primary scorer for Penn State. Prior to these last contests, the lone senior on the Nittany Lions was reduced to a leadership role, where most of his contributions are limited to intangibles that don’t show up in the box score.

While that’s been largely the story for Reed’s entire collegiate career, the Atlanta native saw his role morph as the Penn State absences piled up, and the wing with a career average of 4.1 points per game reached double-digit scoring in his last six outings.

He scored 18 points twice, also over those couple of weeks, only one short of his career high.

Over that stretch, Reed has been efficient despite not being a primary scorer; in those six games, he has averaged over 30 minutes and shot over 50% in every game but one.

Where does the scoring come?

While Reed took the scoring reins over the past couple of weeks, scoring also became more spread out in atypical ways. Eli Rice, Mingo, Reed and Dilione all took times as leading scorers, and those four contribute their baskets in different ways.

Rice has the three-point shot, Dilione the slick handles, Mingo a unique downhill speed and Reed a unforeseen veteran scrapiness. The Nittany Lions have developed the ability to score by anyone and in any way; the only uphill battle now is doing so consistently and together.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘It's about bringing everyone together’ | THON hosts 2026 showcase
author: Reese Igou | The Daily Collegian
description:
THON hosted their annual 2026 Showcase on Sunday Night, having 13 teams compete in the Schwab Auditorium.

The teams participated in the showcase for a chance to receive an extra performance slot during THON weekend, alongside various amounts of crediting funds for their organization. With THON commencing in less than 19 days, the event drew a number of students, volunteers and community members.

THON is the world's largest student-run philanthropy that aims to provide emotional and financial support to Four Diamonds families who have been impacted by childhood cancer.

“I think … a lot of people think of THON as just this 46-hour, no sitting, no sleeping marathon, and it's important to realize that it's more than just that,” Mia Michel said. “It's about bringing everyone together.”

Michel, a third-year studying psychology and Spanish, and her colleague, Taylor Casavant, believe THON is the sum of all of its parts; with every organization, contributor, dancer and family forming THON into what it is today.

“It’s the greatest thing that I’ve ever been a part of,” Casavant, a fifth-year studying computer science, said.

The showcase started with enthusiasm as performers showcased all of the work they had put into preparing for the event. With support from family, friends and other attendees, the night was full of cheers and spirit, participants performed acts to a variety of songs, from Coldplay to the Black Eyed Peas.

“We are incredibly proud to be a part of a community that shares both a deep passion for music and a strong commitment to the fight against childhood cancer,” a representative from The Coda Conduct, a co-ed acappella group, said in a speech. “We are honored to stand in support of our friends in unison in the incredible work they do for THON.”

The judges for the night were Ben Roitman, executive director of THON; Kristen Donahoe, THON’s volunteer logistics director; and the Fleagle Family, Braden, Easton, Troy, Alison and Darin, who are part of Four Diamonds.

After deliberation, the judges announced that the winner of the 2026 THON Showcase was Whiplash, an all girls hip hop dance team. This first place win gave the group $3,000 in crediting funds and an extra performance spot during THON weekend.

“It’s just honestly indescribable,” Grace Pearson, an alumni relations and corporate outreach chair for Whiplash, said. “It means another chance to spread our mission, our love for THON and our love for Whiplash. It’s such a big honor.”

Pearson, a fourth-year studying agribusiness management, the win "means the world" to her, and that it's an "amazing feeling."

“I am feeling beyond thankful,” Julia O’Donnell, a fourth-year studying rehabilitation and human services and family relations chair for Whiplash, said. “We all THON for our special reasons and all of us being seniors, it's our last one and we’re gonna make it the best one.”

The second place prize of $2,000 went to Orchesis, Penn State’s oldest dance team. Third place was Penn State's largest dance group, Volé, winning $1,000. Fourth place, winning $400, was the Urban Dance Troupe, an inclusive hip hop team. In fifth place was Tapestry, Penn State’s tap dancing team, winning $250.

“There is not a time we perform that we don’t say ‘This is for THON,’” Aleana Worsley, a fourth-year elementary education major and overall THON chair for Whiplash, said. “This is For the Kids.”

title: Former Penn State RB commit Kemon Spell pledges to Georgia
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Despite being crystal balled to Penn State, 2027 running back Kemon Spell is headed to Georgia.

Spell announced his pledge to the Bulldogs on Monday, just less than four months after he decommitted from Penn State following the departure of James Franklin.

The 5-star recruit is ranked as the No. 1 player in Pennsylvania, No. 1 running back and No. 7 player nationally, per the 247Sports composite rankings.

Spell initially committed to Penn State on Aug. 2, 2024, holding true to that promise until Oct. 12, 2025. Matt Campbell and the Nittany Lions’ new staff re-offered Spell on Dec. 10, and he was supposed to take an official visit on Jan. 24 to meet with them at Junior Day, but he never made it to Happy Valley after weather conditions put a dent in his plans.

He was in Athens, Georgia, this past weekend for their Junior Day.

Spell visited Penn State for the Villanova game on Sept. 13 and the White Out on Oct. 27. He was also seen front row at set of ESPN's College GameDay the morning of the Nittany Lions’ bout with Oregon.

The running back plays high school ball at in-state McKeesport, where he ran for 1,681 yards and tallied 10.7 yards per carry in 2024.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women's hockey stays put at No. 4 in latest USCHO Poll
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian

After another weekend series sweep, this one over the Robert Morris Colonials, Penn State remains at No. 4 in the latest USCHO poll.

pic.twitter.com/1ixJLNDS7w— USCHO.com (@USCHO) February 2, 2026

title: Way-too-early prediction of Penn State’s 2026 defensive depth chart
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
After taking a stab at what Penn State’s offensive depth chart will look like in 2026, it’s time to guess what the defense will shape up to be.

Here’s a prediction of what the defensive side of the ball will be next year.

Edge rushers

1. Max Granville, redshirt sophomore

2.Yvan Kemajou, sophomore

3. Ikenna Ezeogu, redshirt senior

4. Alexander McPherson, sophomore

Penn State’s defensive end room is completely revamped from a season ago, with Dani Dennis-Sutton exhausting eligibility and Zuriah Fisher, Chaz Coleman and Jaylen Harvey all transferring.

In turn, the edge rusher spot will be a younger crew next year. The two projected starters are Max Granville and Yvan Kemajou.

Granville missed all of 2025 with injury, but saw his stock rise at the end of 2024 as a rotational piece in the playoffs and notably filled in for Abdul Carter when he left the Fiesta Bowl due to injury.

Kemajou burned his redshirt last year, appearing in 10 games where he notched 13 total tackles and 1.5 sacks. Behind them will be a pair of transfers in Ikenna Ezeogu from Iowa State and Alexander McPherson from Colorado.

Ezeogu will be the rare veteran in the group of defensive ends, having recorded 60 total tackles, and three sacks since 2023. McPherson appeared in 10 games for the Buffaloes, tallying 16 total tackles, six quarterback pressures and a blocked punt.

Defensive tackle

1.Siale Taupaki, redshirt senior +

2. Keanu Williams, redshirt senior

3. Dallas Vakalahi, junior

4. Armstrong Nnodim, redshirt sophomore

Just like defensive end, Penn State will need to fill in holes at defensive tackle with Zane Durant and Alonzo Ford Jr. off to the NFL as well as Xavier Gilliam transferring.

The starters will be Siale Taupaki and Keanu Williams, who both come from UCLA. Taupaki is entering his eighth year of college football, which has featured a handful of injuries and switching from defensive line to offensive line and then back to defensive line.

Williams spent his first two years at Oregon before his last three with the Bruins, and has posted 59 total tackles in his collegiate career.

Behind the ex-Bruins will be Dallas Vakalahi from Utah and Armstrong Nnodim from Oklahoma State. Valkalahi recorded 27 total tackles with the Utes in two seasons while Nnodim had 11 total tackles in 2025 after redshirting the year before.

Linebacker

WILL:

1. Tony Rojas, redshirt junior

2. Cael Brezina, junior

MIKE:

1. Caleb Bacon, redshirt senior

2. Rojas

SAM:

1. Kooper Ebel, senior

2. Alex Tatsch, sophomore

Penn State will need to replace the production of Amare Campbell, who garnered 103 total tackles in his lone season in State College after transferring in from North Carolina and has since transferred to Tennessee.

The bright spot for the Nittany Lions is the return of Tony Rojas, who suffered a long-term injury following the loss to Oregon. Before that, Rojas was playing some solid ball, notching 25 total tackles and a pair of sacks. He’s a strong candidate to be a captain in 2026.

Outside of Rojas, the reinforcements at linebacker come from Iowa State, as the top-three players at the position for the Cyclones a year ago, Caleb Bacon, Kooper Ebel and Cael Brezina, bring their talents to Happy Valley.

Bacon and Ebel combined for 145 tackles, while Brezina chipped in 29 himself.

Another name to keep an eye on is Alex Tatsch, who saw an uptick in snaps to end 2025 and burned his redshirt in the process. He suffered an injury during bowl prep leading up to the Pinstripe Bowl, and there is no current update on his status moving forward.

Cornerback

Outside:

1. Audavion Collins, redshirt senior

2. Daryus Dixson, sophomore

3. Jahmir Joseph, redshirt freshman

Nickel:

1. Zion Tracy, senior

2. Omarion Davis, sophomore

As far as retaining talent, the cornerback room had a successful offseason despite losing A.J. Harris and Elliot Washington II to the transfer portal, back are Audavion Collins, Daryus Dixson, Zion Tracy and Jahmir Joseph.

Collins, Dixson and Tracy all started in the Pinstripe Bowl — Collins and Tracy were starters the whole year.

Collins has been one of the program’s biggest risers over the last few years, earning himself a starting job in 2025 after transferring in from Mississippi State in 2023. In 2025, he had 47 total tackles and three pass breakups in his first year as a starter.

Dixson was a huge recruiting win in the 2025 class, as he was a highly touted prospect from national powerhouse Mater Dei in California. He burned his redshirted and surpassed Harris and Washington for playing time by the end of the regular season, accumulating 22 total tackles and six pass break ups.

Tracy held down the nickel spot, tallying 32 tackles with five tackles for loss a year ago. He missed two games at the start of the year due to injury, where ex-Nittany Lion Kenny Woseley Jr. started, but he has since transferred to Virginia Tech.

Jahmir Joseph is a young player who flashed with a pick-6 against Villanova. He maintained his redshirt, but saw extended run in the Pinstripe Bowl, logging five total tackles and a pass breakup.

Boston College transfer Omarion Davis could be a candidate to be the backup nickel. 2025 was his freshman year, where he played in all 12 games with a pair of starts, recording 13 total tackles. Davis played safety for the Eagles, but has the athletic profile to slot in at nickel with his 5-foot-11, 185-pound frame.

Safety

Strong safety:

1. Marcus Neal Jr., junior

2. Vaboue Toure, redshirt sophomore

Free safety:

1. Jeremiah Cooper, redshirt senior

2. Jamison Patton, senior

Safety is another position where Penn State will see a handful of new faces with Zakee Wheatley off to the NFL as well as King Mack and Dejuan Lane transferring.

Iowa State transfer Marcus Neal Jr. will start at strong safety, coming off of a 2025 campaign where he started as a sophomore, and a third-team All-Big 12 selection. Other than quarterback Rocco Becht, he is viewed to be the biggest addition via the portal for the Nittany Lions.

Alongside him at free safety will be ex-Cyclone Jeremiah Cooper, who was a first-team All-Big 12 selection in 2023, but missed 2025 after four games due to a season-ending knee injury. During his time with Iowa State, he garnered 138 total tackles and eight interceptions.

Cooper started his career as a safety, but moved to cornerback in 2025. However, the path for playing time is easier for him at safety with the room having more uncertainties than cornerback.

For rotational pieces, Penn State has Vaboue Toure and Iowa State transfer Jamison Patton.

Through three seasons with the Cyclones, Patton recorded 79 total tackles and four interceptions. If Cooper starts at cornerback, Patton will likely be the favorite to start at free safety next to Neal.

Toure appeared in 11 games in 2025 after redshirting the year before, notching 13 total tackles and a sack. He flashed in the Pinstripe Bowl with seven total tackles.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘Really proud of him’ | Freddie Dilione V showcases scrappy playstyle to help Penn State beat Minnesota
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Mike Rhoades told his players to “empty the tank” before facing Minnesota, with the team dealing with a smaller rotation due to multiple injuries, and one player in particular seemed to take that to heart.

Guard Freddie Dilione V tied his career-high with 25 points to help lead the Nittany Lions to a 77-75 win over the Golden Gophers on Sunday, but it wasn’t just his offense that stuck out to Rhoades.

“Freddie can make plays, and what I was proud of Freddie today is he played defense,” Rhoades said postgame. “He played defense. He had five rebounds. He was in some scuffles. He was going after the ball today.”

Dilione played with a high motor on defense, totaling three steals in addition to his four defensive rebounds, which is the second most he’s gotten in Big Ten play this season. His steal at the 13:44 mark of the first half led to him making a fast-break dunk to give Penn State an early 15-9 lead.

The redshirt junior’s defense helped set up offensive possessions for the Nittany Lions. Dilione shot 64.7% from the field, which is his third-best shooting percentage of the season.

Entering Sunday’s matchup, Dilione hadn’t shot more than 50% from the field since the Pitt game on Dec. 21. He was held to 8.2 points per game between the UCLA and Northwestern games — a stark change for a player who’s usually in double figures.

“Had a bad stretch the past few games but finally found it again,” Dilione said postgame. “It was really no plan to it, just mental, just stuff I've been doing. Shout out to (point guard Kayden Mingo). He got me the ball.”

Dilione was sitting next to Mingo during a postgame availability, and the two smiled at each other after Dilione gave credit to Mingo. In response, Mingo said that Dilione was scoring on his own throughout the game, highlighting his shot-creation ability.

When he scores on his own, Dilione typically finds his spot: typically a mid-range jumper near the free-throw line. He had two unassisted baskets in the second half, including one at the 6:31 mark to give the Nittany Lions a 69-58 advantage.

Dilione made a few other key plays down the stretch, such as his offensive rebound with 5:02 left in the game, leading to a second-chance bucket by forward Josh Reed. That basket was made possible by Dilione, and it gave Penn State enough cushion to fend off a late comeback attempt by Minnesota.

As the Golden Gophers came storming back, Dilione got a layup to fall to generate a 73-70 Penn State lead with 2:09 left. He was also an option on the final possession of the game, but Mingo ended up keeping the ball for himself.

Regardless, the plays that Dilione showcased Sunday are what Rhoades is looking for out of him moving forward.

“I don't mean in a negative way, but like, we need a dirty Freddie,” Rhoades said. “We need him to be grimy because we all know he could score. And he did that today. I told him, ‘If you don't do that, it's gonna be really hard.’ And he did that. He scrapped tonight. Really proud of him.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Events to celebrate Black History Month in State College
author: Alex Fischer | The Daily Collegian
description:
First observed in 1926 as a week-long celebration, Black History is observed every February in the United States. This February marks 50 years since the celebrations were expanded into a full month.

Here are some Black history commemoration events in and around State College.

Tuesday, February 3

State College National Day of Racial Healing

The State College National Day of Racial Healing is a day for community members to reflect on and foster dialogue about racial relations in their community through keynote talks, discussions and group activities.

This year’s event, themed “Race and Identity: Fostering Healing in Our Communities” will be held on Feb. 3 from 11 a.m.-2:30 p.m. in the State College Municipal Building.

The event is free and open to the public. Those interested in attending can register here.

Thursday, February 5

Terri Lyne Carrington’s “We Insist! 2025” Concert

Jazz drummer Terri Lyne Carrington will perform with a live jazz band on Feb. 5 at 7:30 p.m in Eisenhower Auditorium.

The concert will feature songs from “We Insist! 2025,” a tribute album inspired by American jazz drummer Max Roach. The album is meant to recapture the “sonic and sometimes physical urgency” of the 1960s, and will incorporate elements of gospel, neo-soul, funk, Afro-Latin, West African and blues music.

Tickets are $47 for adults, $33 for those 18 years and younger and $14 for University Park students, and can be purchased here.

Tuesday, February 10

The Joyfull: Cirque Kalabanté Edition

The Center for the Performing Arts will host The Joyfull: Cirque Kalabanté Edition on Feb. 10 at 6 p.m. in Robb Hall in the Hintz Family Alumni Center.

Joyfull events are meant to be an opportunity for people to connect through food and culture through an evening of dining and live performances.

The Joyfull: Cirque Kalabanté is free and open to the public. Those interested in attending can register here.

Wednesday, February 11

Cirque Kalabanté: Afrique en Cirque

Canadian circus group Cirque Kalabanté will perform their show “Afrique en Cirque” on Feb. 11 at 7:30 p.m in Eisenhower Auditorium.

“Afrique en Cirque” is inspired by director and choreographer Yamoussa Bangoura’s experiences growing up in Guinea.

Tickets are $56 for adults, $19 for those 18 years and younger and $14 for University Park students, and can be purchased here.

Friday, February 13

Douglass Day 2026

Douglass Day 2026 will be held on Feb. 13 from noon to 3 p.m. in the Dewey Collaboration Commons, which is on the ground floor of the Pattee Library.

Held annually in honor of abolitionist Frederick Douglass, participants work to transcribe public records and create educational resources about Black history.

This year, participants will focus on records from the Colored Conventions, a series of conventions in the 19th century that were seen as the precursor to African American organizations like the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP).

Hosted by the Center for Black Digital Research, Douglass Day 2026 is free and open to the public. Those interested in attending can register here.

Saturday, February 14

Black Excellence in STEMM Brunch

The National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) at University Park will host their second annual Black Excellence in STEMM Brunch on Feb. 14.

This year’s event, themed “For the Love of Science,” will be held from 11 a.m.-2 p.m. in 101 Huck Life Sciences Building.

Monday, February 16

The Ethnic Heritage Ensemble Concert

Jazz ensemble Ethnic Heritage Ensemble will have a concert on Feb. 16 at 7 p.m. at Manny's Live Performance Space.

Founded in 1973 by percussionist Kahil El'Zabar, the group combines African and African American music to create an “electrifying mix of spiritual jazz and African rhythms.”

Tickets are $35 for general admission and $20 for students, and can be purchased here.

Friday, February 20

PRCC’s Black History Month Fun Friday 2026

Black History Month Fun Friday 2026 will be held on Feb. 20 from noon to 3 p.m. in Heritage Hall in the HUB-Robeson Center.

The event is hosted by the Black Caucus and Black Graduate Student Association, in collaboration with the Paul Robeson Cultural Center, and will include food, activities and music.

Saturday, February 28

African American Storytelling with Momma Pam Pam

The Schlow Centre Region Library will hold its annual African American Storytelling event with childrens’ storyteller Momma Pam Pam on Feb. 28.

The event will be held from 10:30-11 a.m. at the Downsbrough Community Room in the Schlow Library. The event is recommended for children ages 2-6, but all are welcome.

Thursday, March 5

Margaret Nagawa Curator Talk

Margaret Nagawa, a Ph.D. candidate in contemporary African art at Emory University, curated “Insistent Presence: Contemporary African Art from the Chazen Collection,” an African art collection that will be on display at the Palmer Museum of Art through May 10.

Nagawa will be giving a talk about the collection on March 5 from 6 p.m.-7 p.m. at the Palmer Museum.

MORE CAMPUS CONTENT

title: ‘It's really eye opening’ | How dancers prepare for 46 hours in the BJC
author: Emma Naysmith | The Daily Collegian
description:
With THON Weekend 2026 just a little over two weeks away, it’s time for dancers to begin preparing for the highly anticipated 46 hours.

THON is the world's largest student-run philanthropy that aims to provide emotional and financial support to Four Diamonds families who have been impacted by childhood cancer.

Dancer Relations Committee Outreach Coordinator Olivia Johnston said THON provides several resources for dancers to help prepare themselves for the long weekend.

Some of these resources include dancer wellness packets, a more thorough dancer wellness guide, a dancer survival guide and the opportunity to attend a virtual dancer panel where first-time participants can ask previous dancers questions.

“There isn't a specific plan we recommend, like a step-by-step guide of how to perfectly prepare to stand for 46 hours,” Johnston, a fourth-year studying psychology, said. “In general, we suggest to hydrate, eat healthy, light workouts, nothing too strenuous on your body and definitely stretch.”

Johnston also mentioned dancers are encouraged to get ahead on sleep and build their immunity prior to the weekend. Additionally, she said another huge tip is to begin reducing caffeine intake and even entering a dry period to help further avoid any illnesses or withdrawals.

THON dancers are also supported by Dancer Relations Committee members (DRCM) who they’re encouraged to meet prior to the weekend. Johnston said these committee members are “well-rounded” in their education to help support dancers in numerous instances.

“They have all the specific times that they need to know, special event times, floor event times, anything that will keep them entertained,” Johnston said. “They also are being educated on mental health tips and tricks and how to deal with … the mental aspect of dancing for 46 hours.”

Second-generation THON dancer Maddie Langlois danced last year with Alpha Kappa Psi and said it was an amazing experience to have been a part of.

Langlois, a fourth-year studying marketing, said THON does a lot to provide dancers with resources and support. She remembers when struggling at one point, her DRCM stepped in and was “so helpful.”

“Even though that was one of the hardest weekends, it's only a fraction of what some of these families are dealing with,” Langlois said. “It's really eye opening and has really altered the path of my life and how I view things.”

Langlois said it was difficult to prepare for standing, but believes mental preparation can make a significant impact.

“Your feet are going to hurt and you're going to be tired,” Langlois said. “But if your mind is still with it, then I think that really helps.”

Throughout the weekend, Langlois remembers thinking about her organization's THON families through the Adopt-a-Family (AAF) program, and particularly one child who was going through a difficult time.

“If you can think of something that's why you're THON-ing … that can be really helpful to say it to yourself, and stick with that throughout the weekend,” Langlois said. “Because then you're like, ‘This is why I'm here. This is why I'm doing this. This is super important to me.’”

Benjamin Guenther found out in November that he was chosen to dance by his brothers at Delta Sigma Pi, alongside two of his roommates.

Physically, Guenther, a fourth-year studying agricultural and biorenewable systems management, said he and his fellow dancing brothers have started eating clean, avoiding large crowds to prevent sickness and staying physically in shape. He even said that he and about 30 of his brothers ran the Philadelphia Half Marathon together.

“We keep thinking of how hard our brothers are working, how hard they have worked, not only just for THON Weekend, but this whole entire year is a fundraising year in total, and then just helping our families, knowing that this isn't a fight that they have to go through for a year,” Guenther said. “This is a fight they have to go through their whole entire life. We just have to stand for 46 hours.”

Guenther also said he is looking forward to DSP’s THON gala, where all of the dancers, THON chairs and AAF families have the opportunity to speak.

“Seeing how we've really been able to give into our families, lets you put down everything … and really allow for yourself to become more prepared for THON Weekend,” Guenther said. “It really allows for our dancers to become extremely motivated for this weekend, and to see how hard every single brother has worked, and see how much our families really have appreciated that.”

Guenther said DSP THON enforces the idea that THON is a community, a home and a place for all — whether it be your first THON or your last.

“From an internal perspective on THON, it's impossible to explain, but from an external perspective on THON, it's impossible to understand,” Guenther said. “You could go around anywhere in the country, and you're not going to find something like this.”

MORE THON CONTENT

title: 2016 is making a comeback. Here’s what trends we should leave, revive
author: Talia Rittenhouse | The Daily Collegian
description:
Entering the new year, it’s time to transport back to the beloved era, 2016.

Picture it — it’s giving Tumblr, palm trees, Justin Bieber in his prime and selfies galore.

Many trends emerged in 2016 across fashion, makeup and various styles. However, some should stay back in those years of frappuccinos, Dubsmash and ombre Instagram filters. On the other hand, some trends should absolutely be welcomed back in 2026.

Here's what we should leave in 2016 and bring back in 2026.

Leave in 2016

Flower crowns

Most popularly purchased at Claire’s, Justice and pretty much any store at this time.

I think this one will be widely agreed upon to leave in 2016. I’m not sure people will enjoy struggling to see the boards in class, dodging the arrangements of flowers atop students’ heads.

While I understand there’s a vision here with the springtime fashion, in 2026, especially in the winter, it's not the time to bring this back.

Not to mention how uncomfortable they were, getting stuck in people’s hair — I'm surprised the trend didn’t end sooner, 10 years ago.

Colored sunglasses

Now this one can remain in 2016, the classic Five Below colored rim and colored lens sunglasses.

Personally, I had an embarrassingly large collection of these, and I’m sure I’m not alone in this statement, considering the generation of students here at Penn State.

They came in any color you could imagine, sat on the shelves at almost every store, and yet, the trend only lasted a year or so, at least it should have.

So yes, these were still being worn in 2018, but that is not an explanation to why they should return and disrupt fashion 10 years later.

Infinity Scarves

These were perfect for their time. They were stylish with a sweater and jeans, but only in 2016.

Now in State College, our infinity scarves have slowly morphed into the scarves we wear on campus to keep warm in the treacherous wind and negative temperatures.

However, this does not mean they need to return in polkadot patterns, plaid and other prints, nor stay on throughout classes.

So again, and respectfully, let’s stick to this trend in keeping warm, and not as a revived style.

Revive in 2026

Jean shorts

Now this one I would love to see make a comeback in 2026.

While jean shorts can be uncomfortable, they provide an easy and simple go-to outfit option for the spring and summer.

That said, please, oh please, the studded jean shorts do not need to make a reappearance. In combination with styles these days, I think our wardrobes would slowly begin to resemble the Justice displays from our local malls with this style of shorts.

But jean shorts are a perfect staple, just like the jeans students wear to class and out at night.

Baby Lips and EOS

Lip glosses and chapsticks are still a current trend this year, ranging from Summer Fridays to Burt's Bees.

I see this as a perfect opportunity for EOS and Maybelline Baby Lips to come back to our makeup drawers and bags on a night out.

And talk about cute — students at all schools can fall in love when a package is colorful, appealing and contains a high-quality product.

They’re compact and sold in a variety of scents, ranging from fruity to sweet, just like the lip glosses used today.

Dark eyeshadow

If done correctly, I see no issues with the return of dark eye shadow.

The bold look is fun on occasion, especially when adding glitter. A dark eyeshadow color can make your eyes pop and bring your makeup look together.

However, brightly colored eye shadow is a different story.

Using blue eyeshadow is a little too ‘80s to bring back as a 2016 trend, but the choice is yours in how you want to take advantage of this trend.

MORE BLOGS

title: This week in State College
author: Neel Ved | The Daily Collegian
description:
As students near the end of their first month of the spring semester, there are a number of events happening on and off campus to enjoy.

Here are some events this week to take a break from studying.

Monday, February 2

Yoga & Meditation

From 12:30-1:30 p.m., there will be a yoga and meditation session happening at the HUB-Robeson Center in Room 232.

Anyone is welcome to let their mind and body fall into a rejuvenating yoga and meditation practice. All the sessions are led by certified instructors and everyone is welcome to come with experience or no experience.

Supplies are limited, so it is recommended to bring your own.

Charleston Lesson and Social Dance

Happening from 7-9 p.m., the Swing Dance Club will be teaching attendees the Charleston dance, a 1920s jazz club staple. The event will be taking place at the State College Municipal Building.

Attendees are not required to come with a partner and no experience is needed. From 7-8 p.m. there will be dance lessons, and from 8-9 p.m. there will be a dance party.

Registration for this event is required. It is recommended to join the GroupMe for updates.

Tuesday, February 3

Building a Better Budget Webinar

From 12-1 p.m., the Sokolov-Miller Family Financial and Life Skills Center will be hosting a free webinar for students who are interested in improving their financial stability and preventing unwanted financial surprises.

Students can also make an appointment, which is free and confidential, with any financial expert from the center after the webinar to answer any questions they may have.

Wednesday, February 4

Breathe into Balance

From 12-1 p.m. stop by Room 232 in the HUB to learn helpful tips to help you respond to stress in ways you may have never thought of. All are welcome including students, staff and faculty.

Registration for this event is not required.

Five to Thrive - Leadership Traits that Flow Through Change

The Civic Engagement Alliance will be hosting a 45 minute keynote leadership seminar in partnership with Five to Thrive from 5:30-7:30 p.m. in the Flex Theater in the HUB.

This seminar will inform attendees of the five essential self-leadership traits that are vital to succeed in a fluctuating, AI driven world.

Registration for this event is required and there will be free food.

Dancing with the Stars

Happening from 7-10 p.m., Dancing with the Start Live will be making a stop on its 74-date tour across North America at the Bryce Jordan Center.

Tickets can be found on Ticketmaster.

Thursday, February 5

Spring 2026 Housing Fair

The Spring 2026 Housing Fair will be happening in Alumni Hall in the HUB from 1-4 p.m. During this time students will have the chance to meet with local landlords and leasing offices to learn more about the numerous off-campus housing options available.

Open Mic at Print Factory

From 7-9 p.m. the Print Factory in Bellefonte will be hosting open mic. Attendees can come sing, storytell and perform some poetry. Original work or covers are both welcomed.

Doors open at 6:30 p.m. for sign in and the performances will start at 7 p.m. Registration for this event is not required.

Friday, February 6

Art & Chocolate Fundraiser

Happening from 4-8 p.m., 3 Dots Downtown will be hosting an evening full of art, chocolate and the community. This cherished winter tradition has been a key fundraiser for the ClearWater Conservancy since 1999.

This event brings together artists and restaurants to support the conservation. Registration for this event is not required.

Saturday, February 7

Treaty Oak Revival

From 7-10 p.m. the five-piece powerhouse Treaty Oak Revival will be making a stop at the Bryce Jordan Center to perform their new album West Texas Degenerate.

The tour will feature guest appearances from Wade Forster and the Huser Brothers.

Doors will open at 6 p.m. Tickets can be found on Ticketmaster starting at $134.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: Recap | How former Penn Staters performed at Senior Bowl
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
With just over two months until the NFL draft, preparations are in full swing for the graduating Penn Staters that are hoping to hear their name called at the end of April.

A few participated in the Senior Bowl this past week, but none played in the actual game on Saturday, which the American Team won 17-9. They all practiced, however.

Here’s a recap of the week for these former Nittany Lions.

Nick Singleton, running back

Nick Singleton would’ve been one of the highest-drafted running backs last year after a 1,099-yard season, but he opted to return to Penn State for 2025 and use the last of his eligibility.

Unfortunately for Singleton, his draft stock took a slight tumble. He struggled to start the season and eventually had his playing time reduced to make way for Kaytron Allen, but his athletic abilities remained undeniable as he finished his career as the program leader in career rushing touchdowns, all-purpose yards and total touchdowns.

He had a chance to put his athleticism on display at Senior Bowl practice this week, especially impressing during pass protection, but he broke his foot on Thursday, sidelining him for the foreseeable future and any other pre-draft showcases.

ESPN’s Mel Kiper has Singleton as the No. 6 running back available, and he’s projected to be a third-round pick.

Dani Dennis-Sutton, defensive end

The Pinstripe Bowl proved the kind of teammate and player Dani Dennis-Sutton can be in the big leagues, and he took that one step further at the Senior Bowl this week.

Dennis-Sutton was impressive throughout a week of practice, although he didn’t participate in the actual game. He won battles with ease and put pressure on opposing quarterbacks while showcasing his athleticism.

Dani Dennis-Sutton with a win against Kage Casey pic.twitter.com/sM4kTKtiZZ— Max Chadwick (@CFBMaxChadwick) January 27, 2026

The defensive end had a slight injury scare and was down on the field for a bit at one point, but he walked off on his own power and appears to have avoided injury.

Zakee Wheatley, safety
