One of Penn State’s best defensive players this season headed to the Senior Bowl to show scouts what he’s made of, and he earned some hardware afterwards.

Zakee Wheatley was named the Safety of the Week by his fellow participants and the scouts in attendance, a high honor for the former Nittany Lion that’s one of the top safeties available in the 2026 class.

Wheatley measured in at 6-foot-3 and confirmed to reporters that he’ll be at the NFL Scouting Combine at the end of the month.

Zane Durant, defensive tackle

Zane Durant fell short of the expectation set for him in 2025, much like his team, so he headed to the Senior Bowl to prove he’s still a top defensive tackle available in this year’s NFL draft.

Durant seriously impressed throughout Senior Bowl practice, moving right past interior offensive linemen and showcasing his agility and quickness throughout. Additionally, PFF named him a standout on Day 2.

Penn State DT Zane Durant was too quick for most of the interior OL in Mobile pic.twitter.com/91chLFWfPK— Joe DeLeone (@joedeleone) January 28, 2026

The defensive tackle showcased why he was named a preseason All-American by numerous outlets and likely boosted his draft stock as a result.

Kaytron Allen, running back

Kaytron Allen put plenty of good things on tape this season, racking up 1,303 yards and breaking Penn State’s all-time rushing record.

Allen headed to the Senior Bowl to prove his prowess to scouts, where he dazzled in pass protection and displayed his natural burst with the ball. Allen is currently ranked as the No. 5 running back available, per ESPN’s Mel Kiper.

RB Kaytron Allen with the nice cut and burst through the hole, followed by SAF Deshon Singleton flying downhill to make the tackle. Fun rep! pic.twitter.com/RrUhRVdBaD— Brandyn Pokrass (@BPok24) January 29, 2026

The running back also impressed with his vision, which was a big factor in his success this season. Allen also hit 18.61 mph to show off some speed that people usually associate with his counterpart Singleton.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s basketball feels ‘sense of relief’ after win over Minnesota
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State was off to a 0-10 start to Big Ten play this season, and the Nittany Lions were shorthanded due to multiple injuries before facing Minnesota on Sunday.

Despite that, the blue and white managed to pull off a gutsy 77-75 victory over the Golden Gophers courtesy of guard Kayden Mingo’s last-second shot to win. It marked Penn State’s first win over a power-conference opponent this year and ended an eight-game losing streak.

“It's a good sense of relief,” guard Freddie Dilione V said postgame. “Getting our first win in conference is big for us. We just got to carry it over to the next game, and just keep the momentum going.”

The Nittany Lions erupted in celebration after Mingo’s basket. The Bryce Jordan Center crowd was going wild, and at long last to those connected to the program, Penn State picked up a win in Big Ten play this season.

Mike Rhoades’ squad effort was evident throughout Sunday’s game, which came from a “next man up” mentality with frontcourt pieces Ivan Jurić, Tibor Mirtić and Saša Ciani all sidelined. Wing Eli Rice also picked up an injury during the game, bringing Penn State’s rotation down to seven scholarship players.

“Getting the first win in probably the toughest conference in the country is really big,” Mingo said postgame. “It could be anybody's game any night, and I feel like we had a lot of people step up tonight, and we can continue to use that moving forward.”

Prior to Sunday’s game, the Nittany Lions' losses ranged from last-second letdowns to blowouts, including last week’s 94-73 loss to Northwestern and the 113-72 defeat to Indiana in December.

On the other hand, Penn State took then-No. 2 Michigan down to the buzzer before losing 74-72 on Jan. 6, among other single-digit losses throughout the month of January. Now, the Nittany Lions can say they’ve closed out a win during crunchtime in Big Ten play, even after Minnesota evaporated a 10-point lead late.

“It's a relief, without a doubt,” Rhoades said postgame. “You do this long enough, you go through all different emotions and seasons and months. January was not a lot of fun around here. We had stretches of good basketball against good teams, but not good enough to win, and so today was just enough to win.”

Even with all the losses Penn State endured, Rhoades typically always praised his players’ response. He’s said they are a “very coachable” group that’s looking to improve.

Following the win over the Golden Gophers, the players have a positive result to build on. Regardless, Rhoades still has the same review regarding his group of guys.

“I feel for them because you have a certain way you want your season to go or your games to go, and when it doesn't go that way, you can always have issues and problems. We don't,” Rhoades said. “We just got to get better. Today was a little bit of validation that these guys are doing things the right way. I'm really proud of them.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: 'He's so electric’ | Kayden Mingo makes game-winning shot in Penn State’s win over Minnesota
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Kayden Mingo had the ball at halfcourt during Penn State’s final possession against Minnesota on Sunday. Unbeknownst to him, he was about to make arguably the biggest basket of his young career.

The point guard charged down low, pivoted around several times before taking a step into the paint and laying in a game-winning shot to give the Nittany Lions a 77-75 victory over the Golden Gophers. Mingo’s teammates rushed to him in celebration as the Bryce Jordan Center crowd went wild to cap off his strong finish to the game.

“Coach drew up the play for me, and that was all she wrote from there,” Mingo said postgame. “I got downhill, made sure I played like my coaches teach me, and made a good play. He played good defense, though, as well. It felt great. It felt great having all my teammates going to me, congratulate me, and having their trust and my coaches' trust. I give all the thanks and glory to Jesus Christ and my teammates for being there for me and my coaches for instilling confidence.”

Mingo thought on a play before his game-winner that Penn State’s defense would’ve been called for goaltending, which he said would’ve made his squad push the ball down court quickly and try for a fast basket.

Instead, Minnesota was shooting free throws before Mingo’s play. Since Golden Gophers forward Langston Reynolds went 1-of-2 at the line, Mike Rhoades told his team to hold the ball for the last 30 seconds to get the last shot, according to Mingo.

Rhoades could’ve opted to use guard Freddie Dilione V, who scored a career-high 25 points, on the last possession, but went with Mingo as he felt the freshman star was driving well toward the end of the game.

“What I was proud about Kayden there is being a freshman guard in that situation,” Rhoades said postgame. “He didn't panic. He's a strong pivoter. He's a tough kid with the ball.”

Mingo didn’t get off to a fast start in Sunday’s game. In fact, he was held to just two points in the first half and was shooting 1-of-9 to begin the contest.

However, around the midway point of the second half, Mingo made back-to-back layups to get going. He finished the game off with 14 points, five rebounds, four assists and two steals with 6-of-17 shooting in 37 minutes.

“I feel like once my teammates started to make more and more shots, it started to open up and I came out a little bit more aggressive in the second half,” Mingo said.

Mingo also had multiple key baskets before his clutch shot at the end of the game. At the 8:39 mark of the second half, he sank a 3-pointer to give Penn State a 63-58 lead, and he made a layup with 49 seconds left to generate a 75-72 advantage for his squad.

At local media day back in October, Mingo said he’s “a winner before anything.” He had poise throughout the crunch time of the Nittany Lions' victory over Minnesota, showcasing that mentality.

“He's so electric and quick getting downhill,” Minnesota head coach Niko Medved said postgame. “He plays with such balance, too. He's able to get by guys, and he plays on balance. He can play off at two feet. He uses his pivots well. He's an aggressive, attacking kid. He's got a really, really bright future.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Aquino’s five goals propel Penn State to victory over Colgate inside Holuba Hall
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
Hunter Aquino ended 2025 by being named a second-team Inside Lacrosse All-American, and he showed why he was deserving of that honor in the first game of his 2026 campaign.

Aquino, the reigning Big Ten Freshman of the Year, scored five goals in Holuba Hall en route to an 18-14 victory for Penn State on Sunday.

That mark set a new career high for the sophomore out of Easton, Pennsylvania. His prior best-of-three came against Princeton last season, another game that was played indoors.

“He’s a guy that comes out every day,” coach Jeff Tambroni said. “There’s not a moment, whether it’s a practice or a game, where you’re going to see a change in his attitude [or] his confidence.”

That confidence was paramount to Aquino’s strong showing on Sunday. To go along with his goals, he recorded an assist and two ground balls, capping a solid all-around performance.

Last season, most of Aquino’s reps came as a midfielder, but after the departure of Matt Traynor from the attack line, Tambroni dropped the 6-foot-5 star down to replace the PLL-bound Traynor in 2026.

“He’s still learning how to play the position,” Tambroni said. “You have to learn it through the course of the season. It’s a hard position to play. He’s the catalyst of things that are going on on the offensive end.”

Early returns suggest that the change worked for both Aquino and the Nittany Lions as a whole. His six points in his attack debut were the most by any Penn State player.

“(I was) definitely a little bit nervous,” Aquino said, “When I shot the ball into the goalie’s stick, (my teammates) said ‘keep shooting, keep shooting.’ Just having that trust from them makes my job so much easier.”

While Aquino’s season-opener was strong, there will be bigger challenges ahead for the sophomore. Tambroni noted that while he put in a good performance on Sunday, there’s still a lot to learn for the preseason Big Ten Player to Watch.

“He has to be in different situations,” Tambroni said, “and learn how to manage when we’re down, when we’re up, tighter situations, all situations. Throughout the course of the year, we’ll learn a lot more about this.”

Not only was Aquino strong, but the entire offense’s chemistry was clearly on display in the victory over Colgate, with ten different players recording a goal for the Nittany Lions.

Aquino was one of three Penn State players with a hat trick, to go along with fellow attackman Kyle Lehman and redshirt senior Michael Faraone.

The attack unit specifically was strong in the victory, combining for nine goals and 14 total points. Despite Liam Matthews, who recorded 34 points in 2025, being sidelined with an injury, the unit seemed comfortable with one another.

“We love this group,” Aquino said. “We love getting to know each other. The freshman, (Jack) Iannantuono, is an unbelievable player. Lehman is one of the best attackmen in the country. It’s just so easy to play with them.”

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: No. 13 Penn State scores a 196.375, defeats Rutgers away
author: Caroline Riley | The Daily Collegian
description:
Coming off a massive 197.000+ victory last week, Penn State traveled to Piscataway, New Jersey, to try to repeat that performance against a typical Big Ten foe.

Despite being unable to match last week’s huge 197.250, the Nittany Lions still hit 49.000+ on each event to beat Rutgers 196.375-194.575.

Rotation One

Ellie Monahan started the rotation with a few small mistakes, which lowered her score to a 9.775. She was short on a few handstands and took a small on her full twisting double back.

Jessica Johanson’s routine was really strong on the bars. She caught her reverse hecht a little close, but she also had a small hop back on her double layout for a 9.800.

Small hop on double layout.

Elizabeth Leary was strong on the bar. She held on to a close handstand at the end of her routine. Her biggest deductions came from not just a small hop back on her dismount but also a small step after, for a 9.825.

The freshman Ava Cash had a beautiful routine. She showcased her long lines with perfect handstands throughout and had great distance on her piked Jaeger. However, like her teammates, she had a small shuffle back on her double back for a 9.875.

Ava Peidrahita scored a low 9.400 because her start value was lowered after she missed her Maloney to Pak Salto combination. She needed an extra swing and took a hop on her dismount.

Dani Latronica got the team back on track in a huge way with an event-winning 9.925 and a great stuck landing. Penn State took the lead 49.200-48.825.

Rotation Two

Leary opened the rotation with a full twisting Yurchenko. She had a larger than .100 hop, lowering her score to a 9.750. Cash followed up with her own Yurchenko full. She had massive height and just a small hop back for a 9.850.

Allison Kaempfer with her big 10.0 start value Yurchenko 1.5. She was slightly underrotated and had to take a hop back, lowering her score to 9.750. Latronica followed with a strong Yurchenko, taking just a small hop for a 9.800.

Johanson followed up with a similar performance and a 9.800 of her own after just a hop on the landing. Piedrahita, after her mistake on bars, bounced back in a big way with an event-winning 9.925. Penn State widens its lead over Rutgers 98.325-97.575

Rotation Three

The floor was Penn State’s lowest scoring event of the day, coming in at just 49.025. Leary led off with a strong 9.850 after controlling each of her passes. Monahan followed up with a similar routine, scoring a 9.800. She stuck her second pass cold.

Ashley Maul started her routine off with a strong double back, but was short on her second pass, ultimately sitting her front layout down. She scored only a 9.000, putting pressure on the remaining gymnasts to hit.

Bella Misiura got the team back on track with a 9.775. She had some form issues in her front double full and took a slightly uncontrolled step forward, but stuck her final pass cold. Alyssa Kramer had a similar routine with her front double full and solid final pass for a 9.750.

Kalea McElligott closed out the rotation much like it began, with a 9.850. She had too much power on her opening double back and had to move her front foot back as well in her lunge, but had a strong one-and-a-half to front layout to finish.

Penn State remained ahead of Rutgers 147.350-145.975 as Rutgers struggled to score 49.000+ on any rotation.

Rotation Four

Monahan, coming off last week’s career high, was unable to replicate that performance, scoring a 9.775 to start off the rotation. She had a strong acro combination, but was a little unsteady on her full turn. She took a hop forward on her dismount and drifted to the side.

Leary began the string of triple series for Penn State but took a balance check at the end. She also needed a balance check on her full turn. She managed to hold on to her stuck dismount but scored a low 9.625.

Maul nailed her triple acro series and showcased complete control throughout her routine. She stuck her dismount for a big 9.875 in the third spot. She matched her career high.

McElligott started her routine with a clean triple series. Her back leg was a little off on her leap series, and she took a small hop on her dismount for a 9.750.

Kramer had an extremely solid routine. She was a little slow to make her leap connection but had virtually no wobbles throughout her routine. She stuck her dismount to follow up last week’s career high with just a slightly lower 9.825.

Latronica anchored the rotation with a 9.800. She needed to circle her arms twice after her acro series, which was a bit of a wobble, but had a strong rest of the routine, including a stuck gainer full off the side.

Penn State scored the same as the floor for a 49.025 as Rutgers struggled in its final rotation, having to count a 9.550.

Up Next

Penn State heads for the big SEC stage as it takes on LSU in Baton Rouge at 7:30 p.m. Friday.

MOIRE GYMNASTICS CONTENT

title: Penn State men’s basketball snaps eight-game losing streak with victory over Minnesota
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
The losers of its last eight consecutive games, Penn State entered its matchup against Minnesota with one goal: pick up its first conference win.

A Big Ten win has been evasive for the Nittany Lions this season, but the blue and white finally put it together against the Golden Gophers, picking up a 77-75 buzzer-beating win.

“It’s a relief, without a doubt,” Mike Rhoades said about the win. “January wasn’t fun around here. We had stretches of good basketball against good teams, but not big enough, not experienced enough, good enough to win. Today was just enough to win… Today was a little bit of validation that these guys are doing things the right way.

Penn State missed out on getting the opening points after a Dominick Stewart three-pointer wouldn’t fall, leading to Minnesota’s leading scorer, Cade Tyson getting fouled on the fast break and converting from the charity stripe to strike first.

The two sides were trading points in the early running but the Nittany Lions were pulling ahead thanks to Freddie Dilione V and Josh Reed scoring in bunches on their way to a 15-9 lead.

Dilione capped off the day matching his career-high of 25 points while Reed finished with 18 points, just one point away from tying his career-high of 19.

“Those two guys have all the experience… Josh is an awesome young man. He’s a really good teammate. He cares about people… since he got here in June he took the team out to eat multiple times on his dime. Who does that? Being a good teammate and taking care of your teammates and the young guys, that’s important to him… and he’s having the best individual season he’s ever had,” Rhoades said. “Freddie can make plays… he played defense, he had five rebounds. He was in some scuffles going after the ball today… we need a dirty Freddie.”

A Justin Houser basket off the assist by Kayden Mingo gave the blue and white a five point lead before Minnesota coach Niko Medved called timeout.

In basketball, a “kill” is when a team forces three consecutive defensive stops. Minnesota had been unable to get a kill at the six-minute media timeout, a large reason Penn State had been so successful on offense to that point.

As Dilione notched his 13th point, the Nittany Lions captured a 10 point lead and looked just about as good as they have all season with a 31-21 advantage.

The Nittany Lions missed out on extending their lead to 15 points, unable to get anything to fall for a couple of possessions until a Reed three-pointer made it a 39-29 ballgame with just over a minute remaining in the first half.

Penn State took to the locker room at the half holding a 41-31 lead backed by Reed’s 16 points and Dilione’s 13. Reed looked like he was on pace for setting a new career-high if he and the Nittany Lions could keep running an offensive clinic in the second half.

“Having them both as role models and leaders beside me, it’s really good playing with them,” Mingo said about his teammates. “Especially when both of them are playing very well and scoring the ball at a high clip.”

Minnesota again got the scoring started to kick off the second half after a Tyson pull-up jumper, but Dilione responded back and kept the lead right where it was. The Golden Gophers’ leading scorer went up to 11 points on the day after that bucket.

Stewart had a nice finish with contact to make his bucket an and-one as Penn State made its lead 10 points again, but Minnesota’s rebound leader, Jaylen Crocker-Johnson matched the score after being held to just four points in the first half.

Minnesota was really carving away at the Nittany Lion lead with a big-time slam from Langston Reynolds and an Isaac Asuma three-pointer that cut his squad’s deficit to 50-42.

Eli Rice took a big hit to the head after another Reynolds bucket and had to exit the game and go to the locker room, questionable to return.

After losing Rice, Penn State was losing its lead too.

A Grayson Grove jam meant the Golden Gophers were stepping on the heels of the Nittany Lions, cutting the lead to just 55-53. Some chippiness followed, but the blue and white were holding onto its lead for the time being.

Mingo’s first three-pointer of the day couldn’t have come at a better time as his effort gave Penn State a little more wiggle room, with a narrow 63-58 lead with just about eight minutes left to play.

An unsuccessful Minnesota coach’s challenge regarding a block that followed gave the Nittany Lions even more wiggle room as they got the ball back and capitalized with an easy Stewart bucket.

Reed moved just one point away from his career-high mark of 19 after a fadeaway bucket which extended the blue and white lead to 71-61 with three minutes left to play.

Back-to-back scores from Dilione and Mingo made it a 75-72 ballgame with 40 seconds left in the game after Minnesota was breathing down Penn State’s neck, going on a 9-0 scoring run to erase its deficit and get closer to stealing a win.

“I was pissed at the way we were handling pressure,” Rhoades said about Minnesota closing in. “We were fatigued. We were tired. We were really slow throwing it inbounds.”

A Reynolds layup off the fast break gave the Golden Gophers a 76-75 lead with 30 seconds left on the clock for their first lead since the beginning of the game, but a foul took away the score, and Reynolds instead shot two from the free throw, making just one to turn it into a 75-75 game.

On the last possession of the game, Mingo fought his way to the hoop for an improbable bucket with just a second left on the clock to seal the deal and escape with the 77-75 victory.

Injury Report

Tibor Mirtič, who has been dealing with a knee injury, was listed as “out” against Minnesota.

“Tibor came back from his knee and, in practice, hurt his shoulder his first day back,” Rhoades said.

Big men Ivan Jurić and Saša Ciani were both listed as “questionable” with undisclosed injuries entering Sunday’s match and did not see any action.

“Saša hurt his ankle,” Rhoades said. “Ivan was sick as a dog this morning.”

Up Next

Penn State returns to action at 6:30 p.m. on Thursday when it heads to Ann Arbor to take on No. 3 Michigan.

The Wolverines won their last matchup with the Nittany Lions in the Bryce Jordan Center at the beginning of January, squeaking out a 74-72 victory.

title: No. 6 Penn State men’s gymnastics takes victory over No. 7 Illinois
author: Jimmy Blair | The Daily Collegian
description:
After matching Illinois with 317.65 points at the Sam Mikulak Invitational, the sixth-ranked blue and white faced off against the seventh-ranked Fighting Illini in Rec Hall on Sunday afternoon.

The Nittany Lions took victory over Illinois 316.900-310.900. The blue and white were strong on all events, only losing out to the Illini on the High Bar and Vault.

Floor

The blue and white barely got the edge on Illinois on the floor with a score of 52.850-48.350. Matt Underhill continued his impressive campaign as a 13.300 put him in first among the Nittany Lions on the floor. Illinois’ Nathan Whitaker produced the best result in the event with a 13.600.

Pommel horse

Less than a point separated the two sides on the pommel horse, with the blue and white just barely prevailing in the event with a 53.350-52.650. Freshman Ricky Perez came through with a 13.900, putting him in first in the event. Simpson wasn’t too far behind with a 13.600 as well. Brandon Dang posted an impressive 13.800 for the Illini, despite Illinois barely coming up short in the event.

Rings

Luke Esparo dominated on Rings, posting a 14.100 and leading the Nittany Lions to a team victory in the event 53.600-50.200. Underhill added a 13.700, and Akseli Karsikas put up his best score of the day with a 13.650. Illinois’ Hasan Aydogdu led the Illini with a 13.800.

Vault

The Fighting Illini took the Vault by less than half of a point, with a team score of 54.900 to Penn State’s 54.450. Garrett Schooley posted an elite 14.350 for Illinois, alongside Nate Whitaker’s 13.900. The Nittany Lions came up just short in the event, despite Simpson’s 13.950 and a 13.750 from Shaun Smith.

Bars

In the Parallel Bars, Penn State prevailed 53.200-52.900. In the day’s closest event, Simpson posted 13.650, with Luke Esparo right behind with a 13.550. Sam Kaplan posted a 13.650 of his own, leading Illinois in the event. Only eight points separated the two sides going into the High Bar.

In the final event, Esparo finished his day with a 13.450. Karsikas’ 13.700 sealed the victory for the Nittany Lions with a final score of 316.900-310.900.

Esparo won the Gene Whetstone award for best overall gymnast in the afternoon, after putting up solid scores on all four events he participated in.

Up Next

The Nittany Lions hit the road to Lincoln to take on conference foe Nebraska at 4 p.m. Saturday.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: No. 7 Penn State men’s lacrosse uses high-octane offense in season-opening win over Colgate
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
The last time the Nittany Lions were on the field, it was at Gillette Stadium playing for a chance at the National Championship game. They fell in regulation time and entered a long offseason, picking up numerous recruits and building up their roster for the next opportunity to compete.

No. 7 Penn State opened its regular season play indoors at Holuba Hall as opposed to Panzer Stadium against Colgate on Sunday at noon. The blue and white, after a short road block in the second quarter, blazed to an 18-14 victory to claim victory in its first game of the season.

In a high-scoring home opener, both offensive units thrived under the bright lights of Holuba Hall. A collateral of the damage made by the attackers was a tough start to the season for all three goaltenders who saw action.

“Here in Holuba, the sight line is by far the most challenging, so I think that the goalies get it the worst,” coach Jeff Tambroni said. “The background just doesn't provide what an outdoor background will provide.”

Coach Jeff Tambroni elected to try a pair of netminders between the pipes to see who’d fill Jack Fracyon’s cleats. True freshman Preston Hawkins originally started the game but allowed five goals while only making a single save before being replaced by redshirt freshman Hayes Schreiner, who made four saves on 14 shots.

On the opposite end of the field, Andrew Lehrman had a better showing despite the high-scoring defeat. He made 15 saves on 33 shots, stopping many dangerous opportunities along the way.

Hunter Aquino, the reigning Big Ten Freshman of the Year, Kyle Lehman and Michael Faraone each scored hat-tricks in their season debuts. Aquino ended the contest with four goals and two assists, Lehman scored three and assisted on a pair and Faraone tallied three goals and an assist.

“We love this group,” Aquino said. “We love getting to know each other, having (Iannantuono) an unbelievable player and (Lehman) is one of the best attackmen in the country.”

Aquino, formerly a midfielder last season, moved up to the attack position as Matt Traynor was drafted by the New York Atlas of the Premier Lacrosse League (PLL). His first game up front appeared to make no difference to his ability to put points on the board.

Luke Walstrum and Patrick Carragher also had breakout performances, each scoring a pair of goals to shake up the usual gameplan of utilizing Aquino’s lethal shot. They were backed up by four different scorers who added additional attacking depth — Andrew Beard, Jack Iannantuono, Ryan DiRocco and Chase Robertson.

“We don't have one single guy that can't get it done,” Aquino said. “So we put faith in them.”

Casey Quinson was Colgate’s leading scorer with a hat trick of his own. He was followed by Hunter Drouin, Freddy Fowler and Quinn Spillett, each with a pair. The Raiders also had five other players add their names to the scoreboard.

Penn State dominated on the face-off dot, winning 24-11. Tambroni ran a two-player system, utilizing both Colby Baldwin and Reid Gills to win the majority of battles over Fischer Burke and Kyle Rummel. Aquino appeared once on the dot and won his single opportunity.

“Colby, Reid and their wings have done an exceptional job thus far,” Tambroni said. “It's what we'd hoped and expected going into the game, not in any disrespect to Colgate, but they've just come in and worked so hard every day.”

Early in the second quarter, Colgate surged on both sides of the ball, resulting in its first lead of the game after a five-goal swing. Spillett got the Raiders in motion with a bounce shot that evaded Hawkins’ stick.

Then, after Lehrman made a save on Aquino’s dangerous chance, no Nittany Lion defender slid to Andy Croddick as he freely scored to take a 4-3 lead. On the next possession, Fowler compounded Penn State’s woes with a side-arm shot to extend the gap to two.

This was when Tambroni put Schreiner in the cage and the switch appeared to spark Penn State to life. The move kick-started a four-goal swing that resulted in the Nittany Lions maintaining a healthy lead through the remainder of the game.

Once Penn State regained its prior three-goal advantage in the third quarter, 12-9, it didn’t drop below that threshold despite consistent pressure from Colgate’s attack and 10-man ride strategy.

A series of timeouts called by both teams slowed the pace of play considerably late in the fourth quarter as the Raiders attempted to mount a comeback. However, Penn State held on for the 18-14 victory.

Up Next

Penn State returns to Panzer Stadium to face Villanova at 1 p.m. Saturday.

Injury Report

Attackman Liam Matthews wasn’t dressed for the game, although he was seen alongside his teammates on the sidelines.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Fink breaks scoring drought, nets two goals for No. 5 Penn State men's hockey at Beaver Stadium
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Aiden Fink was named Penn State’s MVP last season, and for good reason. The shifty forward led the Nittany Lions with 53 points, 30 goals and 23 assists.

That scoring production had evaded Fink, who’s missed seven games due to injury this season, for the better part of the 2025-26 campaign. But even after Fink’s scoring drought extended to seven games in No. 5 Penn State’s 6-3 loss to No. 2 Michigan State on Friday, coach Guy Gadowsky remained unbothered.

Gadowsky said Fink had actually played “very well” in several areas and that he had no doubt his offensive production would return. Fink made good on his coach’s confidence, netting two goals in the Nittany Lions’ 5-4 overtime loss to the Spartans on Saturday at Beaver Stadium.

“I thought it was great,” Fink said of scoring his first Big Ten goal of the season. “It's just good to be back from injury … It was very cool scoring in that environment.”

Michigan State earned a 17-10 edge in shots on goal to take a 1-0 lead into the first intermission. Penn State’s offense craved a spark, which Fink delivered 13 seconds into the second period.

The Nashville Predators prospect dribbled down the far boards before utilizing a nifty hesitation move to blow past an off-balance Spartans defender. Fink skated into space and wristed one far side to send Beaver Stadium into a madhouse.

Who else, but Aiden Fink!! 😤#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/FpFPD92wZZ— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 31, 2026

It marked Penn State’s first-ever goal at Beaver Stadium. But more importantly, it marked a breakthrough moment for the junior forward, who scored his first goal since Jan. 4.

“Seeing that whole stadium packed, skating out to that blue line (during player introductions), it was the coolest moment ever,” Fink said.

Fink wasn’t done there. With the contest tied 2-2 toward the end of the second period, Gavin McKenna dribbled behind Michigan State’s goal, eyeing his third point of the game.

Like the duo did 16 minutes earlier, McKenna fed Fink, this time with time and space in the slot. And the veteran forward converted, one-timing a snap shot past Trey Augustine’s outstretched glove to give Penn State a 3-2 lead.

72 ➡️ 18 ➡️ GOAL#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/iiNBqBT1Zr— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 31, 2026

“(Fink) is a very smart player. You want to get the puck on his stick,” McKenna said. “He can obviously put the puck in the back of the net, and he can skate like the wind. So whenever I can get the puck to him, if I ever see him open, I know something's going to happen, and I always have to be ready for a play he's going to make.”

Penn State later fell in overtime, their fourth loss in four tries against Michigan State this season. In front of 74,575 raucous fans, it was a demoralizing defeat for a team that had come so close to earning a signature victory.

But the team’s 2024-25 MVP, who’s battled through injury and tough bounces for much of this season, finally found his stride. And for that, Gadowsky left Beaver Stadium with something.

“Since (Fink) came back from a broken thumb, he's done so much for the team,” Gadowsky said. “He's back-checked, he’s been so supportive of his teammates. I love seeing him have offensive success right now, because I know he's not focused on that. He's focused on trying to get this team to win as much as he can. And it's really showing through. He's as good a leader as I've ever seen him be.”

MORE WINTER SPORTS WEEKEND COVERAGE

title: Penn State lands commitment from 2028 CB Deonte Flemings
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Matt Campbell has struck early on the recruiting trail in building for the future.

Penn State has earned a commitment from 2028 cornerback Deonte Flemings.

COMMITTED 🦁#Weare @CoachMC_PSU @CoachTerryPSU @Coach_Broom @dantonlynn pic.twitter.com/EgX0ZKKfgO— 𝓓𝓮𝓸𝓷𝓽𝓮 “𝓓𝓾𝓬𝓴” 𝓕𝓵𝓮𝓶𝓲𝓷𝓰𝓼(2028 DB) (@d_flemings02) February 1, 2026

Flemings visited over the weekend for Junior Day, and held offers from other programs such as Notre Dame, Syracuse, West Virginia and Pitt.

He plays for in-state McDowell High School, which is where offensive lineman Cooper Cousins attended.

Flemings is the first Nittany Lion committed in the 2028 class. Cousins was the first player on board in the 2024 group.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women's hockey's Kendall Butze adds her name to program record book against RMU
author: Steven Pavelka | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State senior defenseman Kendall Butze stepped up big Saturday, assisting on two goals in the blue and white’s 5–2 win over Robert Morris. With the first helper, Butze set the program record for most points for a defenseman (85).

“(Butze)’s an amazing player and also an amazing person, so everyone was so happy when she got it, I wouldn't want anyone else to get it,” Forward Mya Vaslet said postgame. “Obviously, she's leaving her jersey in a better place than when she found it.”

The Cleveland, Ohio, native got her first assist late in the second period to help freshman defenseman Danica Maynard score and put Penn State up by two points. She got her second assist in the third period when senior forward Katelyn Roberts scored the game-sealing 5th goal in the evening.

“She's honestly a great role model, especially on the defensive side. She communicates a lot, and she's always positive on the bench,” Maynard said postgame. “She's a two-way player, so being able to get her points and the stuff that she does, but also defend, I think she's just like an all-around player, and super fun to watch.”

With Nicole Hall, Tessa Janecke, and Matilde Fantin being in Italy for the Olympics, Penn State needed someone to step up, and that is exactly what Butze did against the Colonials after the team started with a 2-0 deficit.

“You can always rely on her for any situation,” Vaslet said. “Like a five on three and we're penalty kill, or if it's a six on five and we are down one and we need an extra player on, we'll put her on. She's a very 200-foot player; she's someone who you can rely on all the time.””

Despite the slow start to the game, Penn State eventually found its stride and hit the ground running, with that unbenign beginning to the game becoming a nonfactor.

“I do think their mindset was good,” Coach Jeff Kampersal said,” things like work against us. But again, this group. I don't worry about it all.”

Kampersal continued to praise his players' preparedness and their willingness to do whatever it takes to win. He also credited the depth of the team, a season-long sentiment, saying that they have a lot of players who are able to fill in and do a lot of things well.

Butze continues to impress down the stretch, as she had her best game of the season a week earlier against Delaware, in which she had three assists and scored a goal. She is on track to score a personal record for most points in a season, beating the 27 she had in the 2024-2025 season.

With the postseason quickly approaching and a milestone-filled regular season coming to an end, the white and blue will continue to lean on their veteran leadership to win games. Butze will continue to be a key contributor as the team faces tougher opponents and her teammates need someone to rely on.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey mounted two-goal comeback against Robert Morris without three forwards
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State’s final series against Robert Morris not only included the first outdoor hockey game at Beaver Stadium, but the first series without three forwards who have been excelling this season.

The Nittany Lions quickly trailed 2-0 in Game 2 against the Colonials. This was a deficit seemingly uncommon for Penn State, and one that some would think an intermission speech could quickly solve. However, it wasn’t a speech that mounted a comeback; it was belief inside the team that led to five unanswered goals and a 5-2 victory.

“This group can self-motivate. They know when they’re doing well,” coach Jeff Kampersal said. “They know when they need to pick it up also.”

The blue and white showed its self-belief every second after letting up the early goal in the second period. With continuous communication throughout the lines and aggressive forechecking, the Nittany Lions were able to develop scoring opportunities.

Mya Vaslet was a part of the surge of offense as she recorded two assists in the game. The graduate student knew that it only took one goal to get the ball rolling.

“No one really has to say anything with this group, it’s kind of like let’s go out there and let’s pick it up,” Vaslet said. “It’s always like let’s have a good response and then obviously Grace Outwater had a nice goal and kind of got everyone going.”

Penn State was able to cap off a historic weekend with a comeback win without Tessa Janecke, Nicole Hall and Matilde Fantin. The three forwards are currently in Milan, Italy for the Winter Olympic Games. Thus leaving Kampersal to adjust his starting lines.

Throughout the season, the Nittany Lions have played games without either one of the three players. However, losing all three at once could leave a larger impact heading into the backend of the regular season.

“Every single person in the lineup can play, and they are all good at something. Everybody can contribute,” Kampersal said. “If we are down one, two or three (players) we’re good. Obviously, we want everybody back, and we can handle maybe a longer run in the playoffs with everybody back.”

The Nittany Lions played with only three lines instead of four due to the absence of the forwards. A potential factor that could lead to tired skaters on the ice. However, signs of any effect have only been in the right direction thus far.

Kampersal’s statement rings true, not only throughout the coaching staff, but the players as well. For Danica Maynard, she believes that the team’s culture is what has been driving them in the last couple of games.

“I think it’s more of the culture within our team. I think everyone knows we have to keep battling and keep playing our game,” Maynard said. “Obviously, with the three that are gone, they’re amazing, but we have a tight-knit group within as well.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Freshman phenom Gavin McKenna makes a statement despite Penn State’s loss on Saturday
author: Chase Fisher | The Daily Collegian
description:
Stars shine brightest on the biggest stages. For Penn State forward Gavin McKenna, there hasn’t been a more important game in his short Nittany Lions tenure than Saturday’s outdoor matchup at Beaver Stadium in front of 74,575 fans.

No. 5 Penn State against No. 2 Michigan State in an event hyped up to the extreme for the past five months. Well, that was just McKenna’s cup of tea. The freshman phenom took center spotlight, like he usually does, on Saturday, and nearly willed the Nittany Lions to a win.

Unfortunately for Penn State, his three-point, two-goal, one-assist effort came up too small against the Spartans. Regardless, he made a statement — he’s going to show up when the lights are the brightest.

“I mean, every game, you want to be at your best,” McKenna said. “It was obviously a big game. A lot of eyes (were) on this game and I thought our team played well. Obviously not the result we wanted. I thought it was a great experience.”

McKenna is no stranger to taking his game to the next level when his team needs him the most. In last season’s WHL playoffs with the Medicine Hat Tigers, he posted 38 points, nine goals and 29 assists. While the numbers look great by themself, they really catch eyes when seen that he did that in only 16 games.

That’s a 2.375 points-per-game pace in a physical, have-to-have-it style of hockey.

But what might be more impressive is his attitude. Guy Gadowsky said that McKenna is a for-the-team player, which says levels about the actual person he is.

It’s no secret McKenna is getting paid big bucks to play at Penn State. It’s also no secret he’s likely one-and-done and into the NHL next year as the likely No. 1 overall pick.

Yet, he’s not cocky or arrogant. He genuinely wants to help the team succeed.

“Well, I tell you what, there's so much that very justifiably is recognized and written about his talent, and it should be, because it's incredible,” Gadowsky said. “However, the more I get to be around Gavin, the thing that I love the most is he is so for this team and I can tell you, he loves being on Penn State campus. He loves being a part of this, and he wants very badly to be a part of it.”

Saturday showed just how much he’s actually bought into Penn State. McKenna said he blacked out after his goal in the second period, and during it, he showed about as much emotion as he ever has while donning the blue and white.

He said he realized how special and amazing the game was going to be while walking through the tunnel and fist-bumping Penn State football players as he made his way towards the ice. He was truly bought into the moment and the opportunity at hand.

“It's been pretty unbelievable,” McKenna said. “I'll forever be grateful for what we got here at Penn State. Yeah, this game, it was special. The amount of effort people put into this game for us, people traveling in to come watch us play, it was special. And, yeah, to just be part of this community at Penn State, I'm forever at Penn Stater, and that was an amazing time.”

MORE WINTER SPORTS WEEKEND COVERAGE

title: No. 5 Penn State men’s hockey feels community support in Beaver Stadium game loss to No. 2 Michigan State
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Despite a heartbreaking overtime loss to No. 2 Michigan State on Saturday, Penn State captain Dane Dowiak left the Beaver Stadium field, turned ice rink, with a belief: “I just couldn’t be prouder to be a Penn Stater.”

The sports culture the blue and white have developed is first-class, and when 74,575 fans showed up in 15-degree weather for the first-ever outdoor hockey game at Beaver Stadium, that sentiment was all the more evident.

“It’s hard to feel negative because of the loss, because this was such an amazing experience,” Guy Gadowsky said. “It’s so incredible to be a part of an institution that supports something like this so well.”

The Penn State community has rallied around the production of this event for months, and on Saturday, it officially became the second-highest attended outdoor college hockey game of all time, and put it among the top 10 highest attended hockey games at any level.

The electric atmosphere was evident from the moment the Nittany Lions made their entrance out of the student section gates to a roaring crowd and a tunnel of fellow Penn State athletes.

“Walking through those gates was pretty special,” star freshman Gavin McKenna said. “Walking through (all the athletes), fist-bumping them all, the crowd, it was amazing.”

The Spartans managed to subdue the crowd less than three minutes in when forward Daniel Russell opened the scoring, but the passion never went away.

The spark in Beaver Stadium was reignited when, less than 15 seconds into the second period, forward Aiden Fink skated around a defender and rang a shot off the top crossbar and past goaltender Trey Augustine.

The lead was quickly taken back by the Spartans, however, after Charlie Stramel fired home a rebound out in front of Penn State’s netminder Kevin Reidler.

Despite the quick goal by Michigan State, the blue and white maintained most of the momentum, backed by the raucous Roar Zone, and were rewarded for it less than five minutes later.

McKenna received a centering pass from Mac Gadowsky and sent the shot into the back of the Spartans' net, jumping into the glass and blowing the metaphorical roof off the stadium.

“I kind of blacked out on that one,” McKenna said. “I think just the emotions in that game, obviously with the crowd, the atmosphere, how tight of a game it was, it was pretty easy to get excited like that.”

Two more goals were exchanged — one from Fink and one from Stramel — to send the Nittany Lions into the final period locked in a 3-3 battle.

Freshman Shea Van Olm was the hero in Hockey Valley, with a highlight reel goal just four minutes into the third frame. After stripping the puck from a Spartan and beating another in a foot race, the forward sent a shot to the top corner of Augustine’s net and gave Penn State its first lead of the day.

The blue and white had all of three minutes to enjoy its lead, before Matt Basgall’s shot from the point made its way through traffic and into Reidler’s net.

Neither team found another score through the final 10 minutes of the period, and Beaver Stadium and all of its 75,000 fans were sent to overtime.

“There’s nothing like Beaver Stadium, like I know that now,” Dowiak said. “That was the coolest environment I’ll ever play in my life, no matter if I make the NHL or not.”

Despite the deafening stadium and some good chances, the blue and white fell to the Spartans 5-4 about three minutes into the overtime period, when Stramel’s game-winning goal completed his hat-trick and collected the weekend sweep.

While a series sweep always stings, the Penn State community gave plenty of reason for Guy Gadowsky’s unit to walk away with gratitude.

“None of us, the players especially, will ever forget this experience,” Guy Gadowsky said. “It was incredible, and Penn State is incredible.”

MORE WINTER SPORTS WEEKEND COVERAGE

title: No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey scores four unanswered in comeback win over Robert Morris
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey returned to Pegula Ice Arena at 6 p.m. Saturday to close a two-game series against Robert Morris following the program’s first victory at Beaver Stadium.

The Nittany Lions battled back from an early two-goal deficit with five unanswered goals to secure the Winter Weekend sweep over the Colonials with a final score of 5-2. The blue and white improved to 26-4 on the season, 18-1 in the AHA.

“The start wasn't ideal,” coach Jeff Kampersal said. “We're definitely ready to play, but we gifted two goals there.”

First period

Penn State faced early disciplinary action in the first period as Leah Stecker was called for cross checking and Abby Stonehouse was caught for a delay of game penalty, giving the Colonials a 5-on-3 advantage. During the penalty kill, Robert Morris’ Taylor Storey took a trip to the sin bin for hooking.

Once the teams were settled at even-strength, Storey took little time to get the Colonials on the board.

Sophie Morrow mishandled a pass on her attacking blue line and gave Storey a breakaway on goaltender Katie DeSa. Storey toe-dragged on her forehand and lifted the puck over DeSa’s shoulder into the top right corner of the net to open the scoring exactly ten minutes into the first period.

The teams once again traded opportunities on the power play. Both McKenna Walsh and Mya Kearns took tripping minors, but both penalties were routinely cleared by the special teams units. Later, a five-minute major was assessed to Linnea Misner for checking from behind.

While on the power play, Danica Maynard put a shot on net that Grace Outwater followed up by crashing the net. Although the puck slid past goaltender Maggie Hatch and passed the goal line, the officials blew their whistles before it crossed and later deemed it a no-goal.

Second period

Rowyn Ringor wasted no time increasing the gap, despite being shorthanded. She maneuvered into the slot and ripped a wrist shot off the iron and into the back of the net to take a 2-0 lead only 14 seconds into the second period.

Outwater responded 19 seconds later. The Picton, Ontario, native blazed down the right side boards and chose to shoot short-side. Her shot landed under Hatch’s glove and squeaked past the goal line to bring Penn State within one.

“It was hugely important that we scored right away, and that kickstarted us into motion,” Kampersal said.

Stonehouse continued the scoring surge just over two-and-a-half minutes into the frame from the same spot as Outwater. She shot cross-body into the hole over Hatch’s blocker-side shoulder to tie the game at 2-2.

Walsh, who scored the game-winning goal at Beaver Stadium, scored the blue and white’s third unanswered goal with 10:56 remaining in the second period to take a 3-2 lead. She won the race to a breakaway before making a swift move to her backhand, sliding the puck past Hatch’s extended skate.

Maynard joined the scoring after performing a spin move in the slot to get into position for a wrist shot that found a way past Hatch’s pad. Penn State went into the second intermission up by a pair of goals.

“When I got in there, I knew that (Mya Vaslet) was in front and she was screaming, so I threw it to the net and it got in,” Maynard said.

Kendall Butze was awarded the primary assist on Maynard’s goal, her 85th career point, which officially set the program record for most career points by a defenseman. The senior already holds the program record for most assists by a defenseman with 71.

“Everyone was so happy when (Butze) got it,” Vaslet said. “I wouldn't want anyone else to get it. And she's leaving her jersey in a better place than when she found it.”

Third period

Leah Stecker was given a five-minute major for cross checking with 16:28 remaining in the game, after a lengthy video review. Although the Colonials struck the crossbar, Penn State emerged without conceding.

Katelyn Roberts brought energy back to Pegula Ice Arena after an extended period of back-and-forth play through the neutral zone. Butze fired a shot that trickled through Hatch’s pads — and while it sat on the goal-line — Roberts lurked nearby to tap the puck in.

Hatch was subsequently replaced in-net by sophomore Lucy Phillips. The new netminder was quickly thrust into action as Catriona Crarer was assessed a game misconduct for head contact.

Then, Kaitlyn Schooley took a slashing minor, allowing Penn State to close the remainder of the game on the power play.

Up Next

Penn State is set to face Lindenwood in Maryland Heights, Missouri, at 5 p.m. Friday and 2 p.m. Saturday.

title: Kendall Butze sets Penn State women's hockey's program record for career points by a defenseman
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another Penn State women's hockey program record has been set.

Kendall Butze, a senior defenseman out of Cleveland, Ohio, tallied her 85th career point in the Nittany Lions' game against Robert Morris at Pegula Ice Arena on Saturday. The figure now stands as the most points by a defenseman in program history.

Her record-setting point was an assist on freshman Danica Maynard's goal, Penn State's fourth unanswered of the game, to take a 4-2 lead in the second period.

Butze already holds the program record for most assists by a defenseman with 71.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State hosts second-largest NCAA hockey crowd ever in OT loss to Michigan State
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
When Guy Gadowsky took over as head coach of Penn State men’s hockey, the program was housed in the lowly Greenberg Ice Pavilion. A complex that resembles a community rink with a ceiling lower than most of the classrooms at University Park. Yet from the moment he got the job, Gadowsky strived for bigger surroundings.

“I think the day I got hired, the question was ‘when are you guys gonna play a hockey game at Beaver Stadium?’” Gadowsky said. “I just didn’t think it was possible.”

As the program grew, so did the stages they played in. From the Greenberg to the Pegula Ice Arena, to NHL arenas for specialty games and the Frozen Four, all leading up to Saturday afternoon. 74,575 fans packed into Beaver Stadium, all clad in blue and white, supporting a program that hadn’t joined the NCAA until 15 years ago.

Days before the game, Gadowsky couldn’t yet imagine what the scene would look like in front of a sea of hockey fans.

“This is going to be new, and it’s certainly going to feel new,” Gadowsky said prior to the game. “All I know is that it’s going to be cold on the bench.”

When Gadowsky first visited the stadium on Wednesday, the gratitude finally sank in. The coach reflected on a decade and a half of success, fronted by Terry Pegula and his place in the program into perspective.

“I’m so grateful to everyone who started this program and everyone who’s gotten success," Gadowsky said. “I don’t think (Pegula) ever thought it’d hit 75,000, but I know he’s very proud.”

When the weekend finally came, Gadowsky led his squad in front of a crowd that had only been topped once in the history of college hockey. They walked through the hallowed gates that have become synonymous with fall nights in Pennsylvania as fireworks shot out hundreds of feet above their skates. The stadium shook as the crowd, who weren’t stuck in traffic, made up for the noise of the late arrivals.

“There’s nothing like Beaver Stadium, and I know that now,” Penn State captain Dane Dowiak said. “That was the coolest environment I will ever play in in my life, no matter if I make the NHL or not.”

As the players made their slow walk into frigid temperatures, representatives of other NCAA teams lined the entryway to greet them. When they lined up for the player introductions, it became clear the Roar Zone had traveled well on its journey across Curtin Road. Every time a Spartan’s name was mentioned, half of the stadium overpowered the PA system with the word “SUCKS” louder than the 1/12th capacity of Pegula Ice Arena could scientifically muster.

Then the Nittany Lions got their chance to be introduced, creating a lifetime memory as the crowd roared at each name and picture on the jumbotrons.

“Just seeing that whole stadium packed, skating out to the blue line with your name called, it was the coolest moment ever.” Aiden Fink said.

The loudest ovation came for McKenna. If there’s one player in the NCAA who could imagine playing in a game more grandiose than Saturday, it’s him. The expected first-overall NHL draft pick now has a memory that will be hard to top without involving a Stanley Cup over his head. McKenna expressed what being a Nittany Lion means to him after a once-in-a-lifetime experience.

“I’ll forever be grateful for what we’ve got here at Penn State,” McKenna said. “This game was special; I’m forever a Penn Stater.”

When the game started, the crowd stayed hot, singing the classic Penn State hockey chants and the football traditions that are commonplace at Beaver Stadium.

Even though the Spartans silenced the energy in the first with a goal, the energy that returned when Fink potted the Nittany Lions’ first goal nearly brought down the west stadium construction site. As fireworks shot off, Fink was dogpiled by teammates while over 70,000 fans jumped and sang along to Kernkraft.

“That was one of those moments where you just look around and take it in,” Gadowsky said. “I couldn’t believe it was for hockey, it’s very humbling, honestly.”

After the game, despite the loss, Gadowsky couldn’t help but reflect on the experience with gratitude. He took the football coach's seat in the Beaver Stadium press room, holding back tears as he thanked everyone involved with making his dream for the program come true.

“It was bigger and more vast than I imagined,” Gadowsky said. “I just never thought I would be able to be on a hockey rink in that kind of environment; it exceeded what I had in mind.”

As the press conference came to an end, singalong the end of Gadowsky’s day at the center of the hockey world and seated in the largest venue the state of Pennsylvania had to offer, the coach was pondered as to if he thinks stadium hockey will return to Penn State. He credited all the university officials under him and offered his support for running it back next year.

“That’s way above my pay grade,” Gadowsky said. “I would love to do it as that was as amazing of a hockey experience as I ever had.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: No. 14 Penn State men's volleyball falls to No. 3 Hawai'i in four-set battle
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
If you ever find yourself a member of a Penn State sports team that uses a ball and you’re playing inside Rec Hall in 2026, chances are it's already an uphill battle, and you’re losing.

Both basketball squads are winless at the venue in 2026, with some poor results in that stretch. These disappointing results create a reality in which the only sports to win their last home outings at the oldest venue on campus were both gymnastics squads.

Yet, the men’s volleyball team, in its final season under Mark Pavlik’s over three decades at the helm, started well on its crusade to change such a narrative, with four straight Rec Hall wins to start the season.

After a disastrous Midwest road trip, in which McKendree snapped the Nittany Lions' win streak with a two-match sweep where the blue and white only snagged a single set, the haunting at Rec Hall continued for Penn State athletics.

In a particularly chilly and sporting-packed weekend in State College, Pavlik’s squad welcomed a daunting foe in the form of No.3 Hawai’i. In match one, the Rainbow Warriors swept the Nittany Lions decisively.

The blue and white kept it close throughout the first two sets, yet a ten-point third set differential sent them packing with a chance for redemption in the second outing – and just like the first, early starts favored Penn State.

That doesn’t mean it went all smoothly for the blue and white. A unit of Jaxon Herr, Ryan Merk, Jaidyn Bethel, Gaige Gabriel, Sean Harvey, Owen Rose and Matthew Luoma started for Penn State, and despite early leads, Hawai’i clawed back and even took the upper hand at times.

Back-and-forth action marked the remainder of the frame until a tied 25 score saw action intensify and clean up, with the all-important first set on the line. Pavlik brought Gabriel back onto the floor.

However, it wasn’t the 6-foot-8 sophomore deciding the action this time, as he so often has this season; stalwart starter Rose logged two crucial aces to determine the set in the Nittany Lions' favor.

With the drama and momentum at a high, the Nittany Lions buckled into the driver’s seat for an opportunity to mount an upset over its island foe, yet instead, Hawai’i immediately drowned out that effort.

It’s not fair to say if the Nittany Lions crashed and burned in that set from behind the wheel, but what is more reasonable is that the Rainbow Warriors may have committed grand theft auto on all momentum behind their four aces en route to a 25-10 smashing.

From there, the blue and white were only visible from the rearview, as Hawai’i rainbowed their score with huge scoring runs, which had no pots of gold at the end of it for Penn State. The Rainbow Warriors snatched the first three points of the third set, via a kill and a pair of Nittany Lions’ attack errors.

At the midpoint of the set, Hawai’i led 12-6 and continued to easily swerve past anything that Pavlik’s unit threw at them. The Nittany Lions attempted to draw back into it, swapping kills with the Rainbow Warriors. That effort was to no avail, however, as by the time Penn State reached 12, its foe had 20.

Bending into the final corner, Hawai’i notched a pair of kills, a point off an error, and an ace to claw closer to victory, and despite a last-minute effort, the blue and white again conceded a set, this time 25-15.

The blue and white trudged out for what appeared to be the final set, and the numbers at the time were discouraging. Hawai’i posted a hitting percentage over four times higher, and led in every single statistical category except digs, which entered the fourth set tied at 20.

The back-and-forth nature of the play returned, however, with the win on the line for Hawai’i, as both units traded kills. Penn State seized the leveled momentum with savvy setups and thundering kills to claw back into the set, and the two squads knotted at 12 points.

Hawai’i showcased its talent on an individual level, getting up to eight aces on the day, and unreal sequences continued to keep this one level. Bethel put it all on the line for Penn State, elevating above the net and even taking a hit off his face, although it didn’t save a point, and the redshirt freshman exited soon after with a tweaked ankle.

The fight for points and pandemonium resumed, with the teams extending into extra points, which let the lid off the Rec Hall crowd. The blue and white navigated to set point via an attack error, yet the two teams couldn’t pull away as the score ticked higher and into the 30s.

The Nittany Lions had match point and attempted to ice the server with a timeout, but the sequence eventually ended in what would’ve been the set-winning point, as the official initially ruled, an interesting call, as the replay showed the ball well inside the line.

Luoma committed an error on the attack, and Hawai’s Adrien Roure smashed the game-winning ace, putting the exclamation point on a 38 to 36 set.

Up Next

Penn State remains at Rec Hall with an opportunity to get back into the win column with a pair of matches against Saint Francis. The first will be the Nittany Lions’ THON Match at 7 p.m. on Friday, Feb 6.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 5 Penn State men's hockey falls in overtime to No. 2 Michigan State in first game at Beaver Stadium
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
STATE COLLEGE, Pa. – A top-five conference matchup is exciting as it is, but take it outside in front of a sea of 70,000 fans decked in white in one of the most storied stadiums in the country, and you have a game for the history books.

No. 5 Penn State took the ice — previously the field — in single-digit, real-feel temperatures for the first-ever outdoor hockey game at Beaver Stadium on Saturday, taking on No. 2 Michigan State in the second meeting of the two-game series.

A back-and-forth battle into overtime saw Michigan State secure the sweep with a 5-4 win.

The atmosphere at Beaver Stadium was electric from the start, with the Nittany Lions mimicking the classic Penn State football entrance from the tunnel to a chanting and packed student section.

The energy from the crowd was quickly stifled, however, when Michigan State struck first less than three minutes into play. A pass from forward Charlie Stramel across the slot found Daniel Russell, who fired a shot past an outstretched Kevin Reidler to give the Spartans an early lead.

Michigan State maintained most of the momentum through the next few minutes and was given an early chance to extend its lead when Penn State freshman Lev Katzin was called for the game’s first penalty.

Nothing came of the opportunity, however, and the blue and white got its own turn on the man-advantage not long after. Forward Anthony Romani, coming off a hat-trick performance in Friday night's contest, went to the box for hooking with about three minutes to go in the period.

Like the Spartans’ earlier opportunity, the Nittany Lions couldn’t get a score. Despite several high-danger chances, star goaltender Trey Augustine showed off his First Team All-American skills and maintained Michigan State's one-goal lead heading into the first intermission.

Both Aiden Fink and Penn State found the momentum they had otherwise been lacking just seconds into the middle frame.

The former Hobey Baker top-10 finalist had just three goals through 18 games this season, factoring in an injury that sidelined him for over two months back in October.

Fink broke his scoring drought just 13 seconds into the second period, after maneuvering around a defender and firing a shot off the top crossbar to even the score.

The tie game was short-lived, however, when Stramel collected a rebound out in front of Reidler about three minutes after Fink’s score to retake the lead for the Spartans.

Despite Michigan State’s goal, the blue and white continued to hold most of the momentum, and Beaver Stadium could sense it.

To the roar of the crowd, star freshman Gavin McKenna found a centering pass from Mac Gadowsky and sent a shot up and over the shoulder of Augustine to tie the game near the halfway mark of the middle frame.

It was Penn State dominance for most of the remaining second period, playing with physicality and stifling any offensive momentum the Spartans previously had.

The Nittany Lions’ first lead of the series came late in the middle frame, when Fink found his second of the game with a slapshot off a feed from McKenna that made the overflowing student section erupt.

Despite playing its strongest period of the series, the blue and white couldn’t hold on to the lead as the clock ticked down.

A trip from Shea Van Olm gave the Spartans a late power-play opportunity, and with just two seconds on the clock, Stramel notched his second score to send the two Big Ten foes into the final 20 minutes tied at three goals apiece.

Van Olm made up for his earlier penalty, retaking the lead for the Nittany Lions just four minutes into the final period. The forward stripped the puck from Maxim Štrbák and used speed to beat a defender, firing a shot to the top corner of the Spartans’ net.

Once again, the team in front couldn’t hold on to the lead, and Michigan State answered with a goal of its own just minutes later to even the score.

All the back-to-back action came to a halt for the final 12 minutes. Neither side could notch the go-ahead goal as the horn sounded, and Beaver Stadium was sent to overtime.

It took three minutes for Michigan State to end it and secure the sweep, after a back-and-forth overtime period.

Stramel registered a hat trick when he was left all alone in front of Reidler, and sent a shot to the top crossbar to register the 5-4 win.

More Winter Sports Weekend Coverage

title: Way-too-early prediction of Penn State’s 2026 offensive depth chart
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
It’s never too early to think about next year.

Ahead of winter workouts, here’s a way-too-early prediction of what Penn State’s offensive depth chart will look like in 2026.

Quarterback

1. Rocco Becht, redshirt senior

2. Alex Manske, redshirt freshman

3. Connor Barry, redshirt junior

4. Peyton Falzone, freshman

5. Kase Evans, freshman

The starting quarterback is an obvious one, as Rocco Becht transfers to Penn State after three years leading the offense at Iowa State. There’s a natural fit for him in State College, following Matt Campbell, offensive coordinator Taylor Mouser and quarterbacks coach Jake Waters.

Behind Becht, there will be a competition for the backup spot between Alex Manske and Connor Barry. Manske also joins the Nittany Lions following a freshman year with the Cyclones while Barry heads to Happy Valley with one year of eligibility left after playing for Division III Christopher Newport in Virginia with a brief stint at Appalachian State beforehand.

Despite only playing in three games with limited numbers in 2025, Manske should have the edge in this battle as a former four-star recruit, who Iowa State believed was the quarterback of the future behind Becht. Barry should provide a veteran presence in the No. 3 role, coming off of a career at Christopher Newport where he’s thrown for 5,561 passing yards and 55 touchdowns and most recently winning his conference’s Offensive Player of the Year.

Rounding out the room are a pair of freshmen in four-star Peyton Falzone and three-star Kase Evans. Walk-on Jack Lambert is the only quarterback on roster who returns from a season ago.

Running back

1. Carson Hansen, senior

2. James Peoples, junior

3. Quinton Martin Jr., redshirt sophomore

4. Cam Wallace, redshirt sophomore

Iowa State transfer tailback Carson Hansen should be the starter come the season-opener against Marshall. He’s coming off of a 2025 campaign where he was a second-team All-Big 12 selection, rushing for 952 yards and six touchdowns.

With that being said, this job won’t be handed to Hansen, as Quinton Martin Jr. and Ohio State transfer James Peoples will more than likely be in the mix.

Last year, Peoples totaled 344 rushing yards and three touchdowns as the third Buckeyes’ tailback on the depth chart behind Bo Jackson and CJ Donaldson. Martin didn’t touch the ball during the regular season for Penn State, but exploded in the Pinstripe Bowl, recording 20 carries for 101 yards.

There should be a healthy dosage of all three running backs to start the year, but any of them can emerge as the lead back. However, there’s a good chance that this is a running back by committee approach, with the trio all seeing some form of a role.

Cam Wallace, who has shown flashes and opted to return for 2026 despite initially entering the transfer portal, will be a key depth piece.

Wide receiver

X-receiver:

1. Chase Sowell, redshirt senior

2. Peter Gonzalez, redshirt sophomore

Y-receiver:

1. Koby Howard, sophomore

2. Keith Jones Jr., redshirt sophomore

Z-receiver:

1. Brett Eskildsen, junior

2. Lyrick Samuel, redshirt freshman

The starting three wideouts on-paper seem to be clear with a pair of Iowa State transfers in Chase Sowell and Brett Eskildsen as well as Koby Howard returning to Penn State for his sophomore year.

As far as where they line up on the field, that’ll be up in the air. Sowell will likely be on the outside, while Eskildsen or Howard can either play on the outside or in the slot.

A season ago, Sowell totaled 32 receptions for 500 yards and two touchdowns while Eskildsen notched 30 catches for 526 yards and five touchdowns. Howard garnered seven receptions for 133 yards in Year 1 as a Nittany Lion, but received rave reviews throughout the course of the campaign.

Peter Gonzalez, Lyrick Samuel and Grambling State transfer Keith Jones Jr. should be the next group up.

Tight end

1. Andrew Rappleyea, redshirt junior

2. Benjamin Brahmer, senior

3. Gabe Burkle, redshirt senior

4. Finn Furmanek, redshirt junior

Andrew Rappleyea and Iowa State transfer Benjamin Brahmer will be the surefire starting tight ends, making them a way-too-early contender for best tandem at the position in the Big Ten.

Rappleyea took over as the top Penn State tight end by the end of the 2025, recording 20 catches for 180 yards and three touchdowns in the final three games of the year. Brahmer, a 2025 second-team All-Big 12 selection, has 977 receiving yards and nine touchdowns through three seasons with the Cyclones.

Gabe Burkle, another ex-Iowa State tight end, should round out the crew of top players at the position. He accumulated 54 receptions for 607 yards and two scores in four years with the Cyclones.

Finn Furmanek will be a key depth piece, as the State College native saw a key role on special teams as well a year ago. Per Sean Fitz of On3, he was put on scholarship.

Offensive line

Left tackle:

Anthony Donkoh, redshirt junior

Owen Aliciene, redshirt freshman

Left guard:

Trevor Buhr, redshirt junior

Malachi Goodman, redshirt freshman

Center:

Brock Riker, redshirt sophomore

Dom Rulli, redshirt senior

Right guard:

Cooper Cousins, junior

Goodman

Right tackle:

Garrett Sexton, redshirt sophomore

Aliciene

Anthony Donkoh is the lone starter to return from 2025, as the rest of the crew is off to the NFL draft. He started at right guard, but with him being the best player, and experience as the starter at right tackle, he could shift over to left tackle to protect Becht’s blindside.

At the other tackle spot, it’ll be a battle between Garrett Sexton and Owen Aliciene. Sexton was the backup right tackle to Nolan Rucci last year, while Aliciene was the third-string left tackle behind Drew Shelton and now-Florida transfer Eagan Boyer. With Sexton having one more year under his belt, he should have the upper hand in this position battle.

For guards, Cooper Cousins and Trevor Buhr should lock down the starting spots. Cousins has been a rotational piece the past two seasons, burning his redshirt in 2024 as a freshman, and starting in the Pinstripe Bowl. Buhr appeared in eight games for Iowa State last year, starting in six of them.

At center, it’ll be a battle between Texas State transfer Brock Riker and walk-on-turned scholarship player Dom Rulli, who started in the Pinstripe Bowl.

Rulli has done some good things for Penn State, notably on special teams as the punt protector, but Riker started in all 12 games in 2025 and was a highly sought after player in the portal by Power Four programs. He also was also a second-team freshman All-American via The Athletic.

Malachi Goodman is a versatile piece off of the bench, who can play either guard or tackle. He came to Penn State as a tackle but practiced at guard under former position coach Phil Trautwein.

The 6-foot-6, 315-pound redshirt freshman was a highly touted recruit, ranking as a high four-star, but didn’t see the field his freshman year.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Practice observations | Penn State women’s lacrosse scrimmages ahead of season-opener
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is just over a week from one of its most anticipated seasons in several years under coach Kayla Treanor’s first year.

The Nittany Lions held an open viewing session for media and fans, featuring two quarters of scrimmage and one quarter of situational work.

After 45 minutes of action, here’s what to expect from this year’s Penn State team.

Strong attack

The White team wasted no time getting down the field after winning the opening faceoff, led by sophomore Allie Meyer. A little over one minute into the game, Meyer scored the scrimmage’s first goal against starting goalie Sydney Manning.

The White team’s success continued midway through the first period as fellow sophomore Ellie Wisch put her team up 2-0.

Friday’s scrimmage was a high-scoring affair through 15 minutes, with goals by Emma Kelly, Delaney Radin and Rocquette Allen.

The second period was slightly slower after four minutes, with neither side able to score. However, things got going after Allen secured her second goal of the day.

The Blue team ultimately took a commanding lead to win the scrimmage with another goal from Wisch and the first goals of the game by Maddie Greco, Erika Ho and Payton Wainman.

Clean play

It was nearly five minutes of play without any turnovers for either team. Treanor’s offense was playing crisp, clean lacrosse.

While multiple passes went astray by the end of the game, the two sides combined for only a few turnovers from pressure and carelessness.

The scrimmage featured several fouls from both teams, with many players being shown the green card and taken off the field for the minute-long violation.

Team depth

Nearly every player saw the field in Friday’s scrimmage, showcasing the depth of Treanor’s squad this year.

That strength was on display through the opening period with the White team — played by a majority of underclassmen — leading the charge.

Two sophomores scored the opening two goals, and freshman Allen scored two of her own.

Goalkeeper questions

While Sydney Manning has been Penn State’s premier goalkeeper throughout her first two seasons, starting in 26 out of 32 games, she wasn’t the star on Friday.

Senior Emily Bette was the goalkeeper to watch in the team’s scrimmage, recording two saves against two goals in the first quarter.

The Albany, New York, native had a hard task while defending the net against Penn State’s starters. However, her second save came against Ho, the Nittany Lions’ leading scorer last season.

MORE LACROSSE CONTENT

title: Penn State wrestling’s PJ Duke loses first match under Nebraska’s slow-paced style
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Nebraska wrestled a visually frustrating style against the Nittany Lions. A majority of matches saw the Cornhuskers keeping their knees to the ground and backing off engagement, looking to pick a spot to potentially take down the high-powered Penn State.

The reaction from the Nittany Lions was a show of apparent frustration across multiple matches, including Mitchell Mesenbrink urging LJ Araujo to take action in his match and Levi Haines nearly shoving Christopher Minto off of the stage.

“You’re not always going to have your best night, and as a team, maybe we were a little flat,” Cael Sanderson said. “I think the guys had to get tough to battle some really good wrestlers.”

While the upper classmen let their emotions fly, one freshman kept his composure in a low-scoring match, despite suffering the first loss of his collegiate career in controversial fashion.

PJ Duke surged up to the top three of the 157 pound weight class throughout the first part of his first season, entering his match at the Bryce Jordan Center undefeated. In his way was the defending national champion at his weight, No. 5 Antrell Taylor.

From the outset of the match, Taylor stayed low, not allowing Duke any leverage to get to his legs. Despite multiple attempts from the former U20 World Champion, Taylor was rarely in real danger due to his ability to back away from his opponent.
