title: Penn State men’s basketball hits the trail to the Midwest in search of Big Ten spoils
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
The stage is set at Welsh Ryan Arena in Evanston, Illinois, where Penn State meets Northwestern in what is the marquee matchup of the week in the Big Ten, but not for all.

It’s not the game to watch this week because this is a clash of titans of talent, but because, just like a Friday at work cut short, someone’s going home happy.

For the Nittany Lions and their fandom, the Legion of Blue, who’re watching from afar in chilly State College, it’s an opportunity to earn their first conference win, as they're the lone team not to do so.

Although it’ll have to attempt such a feat against a Northwestern squad that’s nothing to snuff at and with almost just as much on the line, as its own fanbase, the Wildside, is one of three not to see its favorite team post a Big Ten home win.

Keep on coming

With this being a friendly home court game for the Wildcats, it’s likely to be a packed crowd as the Wildside consistently shows up to root on Northwestern despite the fractured results, and this game seems no different; they won’t quit.

In Northwestern’s last two home games, it faced daunting tasks against ranked foes Nebraska and Illinois, with the latter game being a near sellout; there’s no shortage of fandom willing to show up despite how hard it gets.

Two days before tipoff, ticket sales at Welsh Ryan Arena mirrored that sentiment, as the cheapest ticket the morning before the upcoming matchup was $44 — the price for the next three Penn State home games is $16 or less.

There’s an attempt to change that, with a winter ticket bundle introduced at Penn State, packaging the Beaver Stadium men’s hockey game debut, a showdown featuring two of college wrestling’s biggest stars, A.J. Ferrari and Mitchell Mesenbrink, and the cherry on top: entry to Penn State men’s hoops hosting Minnesota when it returns home.

Although that’s looking ahead, Penn State needs to endure what looks to be a lively crowd first.

History favors…who?

These seasons haven’t gone well, or as either coach would’ve predicted, maybe past results can hint at the fate in this one. Overall, in the series, the blue and white lead 39-22, with last season’s narrow 84-80 victory swinging things back in its favor.

Despite the emphatic all-time margin, it isn’t smooth sailing in this millennium, as Northwestern only narrowly trails 10-11 at home in the series, suggesting that this one may lean their way. If anything, that favor is only a lean; the last eight meetings have been decided by an average of two possessions, and it looks like that narrow trend will continue.

Each squad retains only one starter from last year’s game, both prominent scorers: Freddie Dilione V for Penn State and Nick Martinelli for Northwestern.

The player personnel has a shot to write new history in this matchup, yet there's an experience gap in the coaching department, to say the least. Mike Rhoades is in the midst of his third Big Ten season with Penn State, while Chris Collins is in his 13th with the Wildcats and is more than familiar with this clash.

Numbers for the nerds

Both these squads, as expected given their matching 9-11 records, the only two in the conference, stack up eerily similar.

Only a single tenth separates their scoring offenses, while only a few more separate their possession metrics. Shooting percentages, regardless of where on the floor, line up similarly, and that trend persists on the glass and assist figures, with Northwestern taking the edge in both.

Evan Miyakawa’s advanced numbers also favor Northwestern, as they hold advantages in pace, consistency in performances, offensive and defensive efficiency and clear-cut roster rank. This results in the Nittany Lions' relative rating of 2.8 looking not as strong compared to the Wildcats’, which is over 11.

Both have bottom-three resumes and quality of losses in the Big Ten this year, with the two alternating spots at the bottom of the rankings.

All this culminates in an edge for the Wildcats, as ESPN expects an 80% chance of them winning, though it isn’t that cut-and-dry.

Behind Martinelli, the Northwestern scoring options are limited. Jayden Reid and Arrinten Page hold double-digit averages, but outside that trio, no one scores more than eight a game. For Rhoades, 60% of his ten-man rotation averages more than that figure, and as a unit, they’re still one of the best teams in the Big Ten at generating steals – both shreds of optimism heading to the Midwest.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Recruiting roundup | New Penn State staff hits the road, hosts 1st Junior Day
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Matt Campbell has his first roster and staff in place at Penn State, so part of the efforts are now focused on building relationships with recruits in pursuit of the future.

Here’s what has happened on the recruiting trail recently.

Sights set on former commits

Prior to the firing of James Franklin, Penn State had the No. 1 ranked class in 2027 via the 247Sports Composite rankings.

Then, during the beginning of the season losing streak and removal of Franklin, all four commits backed off of their commitments.

Now that the dust has settled, and the Nittany Lions have a staff in place, part of their efforts have gone to re-establishing relationships with the former 2027 pledges.

The quartet of ex-commits are five-star running back Kemon Spell, four-star wide receiver Khalil Taylor, four-star safety Gabriel Jenkins and four-star offensive tackle Layton von Brandt.

Spell, from in-state McKeesport Area High School, is being pursued from almost all the top programs nationally.

He was originally scheduled to visit for Junior Day this past weekend, but didn’t end up making it. Still, national recruiting experts have logged predictions for the tailback to restate his commitment to Penn State.

Taylor and Jenkins, also Pennsylvania natives, made it to campus for Junior Day. The returns were positive, as both have scheduled an official visit for the summer. Jenkins included Penn State in his top-eight schools.

That leaves the lone non-Pennsylvania target, von Brant, who offensive line coach Ryan Clanton and Campbell visited at Appoquinimink High School in Delaware. Clanton also visited the offensive tackle a week later at home.

New, old targets emerge at Junior Day

Between targets carrying over from the last staff and ones emerging from the new staff, Penn State’s Junior Day gave a first look on who could be in the future of the program.

Numerous old faces returned to campus for a weekend visit, including in-state targets in four-star 2027 wide receiver Matthew Gregory, four-star 2027 athlete Cade Cooper and four-star 2028 defensive end George Parkinson IV.

Gregory plays for Owen J Roberts High School, while Cooper and Parkinson both play for Malvern Prep, which is where defensive end Jackson Ford attended.

Four-star 2027 safety Larry Moon, from national powerhouse IMG Academy, was also in attendance. He was recruited by the previous staff, formerly playing for in-state Aliquippa High School and Central Catholic in Pittsburgh.

Other previous out-of-state targets were three-star 2027 offensive tackle Lucas Rhoa from California and 2028 defensive lineman RJ Cruz III from Maryland. Cruz plays for the McDonogh School, a recruiting hotbed for Penn State.

A Campbell target from Iowa State, four-star 2027 tight end Cooper Terwilliger from South Dakota, made the trip to State College, too. Add 2027 three-star Tommy Douglas from New Jersey powerhouse in Hun School of Princeton to the list.

Douglas, a tight end, is the son of New York Jets’ general manager Joe Douglas.

And so was four-star 2027 offensive tackle Kyle Kuhn. He was previously recruited by both Penn State and Iowa State.

Recent in-state players who have emerged as targets that made it to Junior Day are Kohl’s Kicking 5-star kicker Domenic Pratton from Central Valley High School and 2028 wide receiver Owen Johnson from La Salle College High School.

Westward expansion

Not only does Penn State have more reach in the Midwest with the Iowa State contingent, but the new staff has recruited the West Coast as defensive coordinator D’Anton Lynn and defensive line coach Ikaika Malloe spent their past few seasons at USC and UCLA, respectively.

Penn State was active in Arizona, offering five-star 2028 defensive end Jalanie George, four-star 2027 quarterback Will Mencl, four-star 2028 wide receiver Roye Oliver III, three-star 2027 defensive lineman Yahzeen Zion, three-star 2028 athlete Keaton Fields and 2028 defensive end Landen Wade. They all play at either Desert Edge, Basha or Chandler, three top-10 programs in the state, per MaxPreps.

The Nittany Lions also dished out offers to California recruits in four-star 2027 safety Isala Aisa Wily-Ava, three-star 2027 linebacker Josiah Poyer, three-star 2027 defensive lineman Montana Toilolo. Wily-Ava and Poyer play for St. John Bosco while Toilolo plays for Mater Dei, which is where cornerback Daryus Dixson played.

To round it out, there was also a quartet of offers in Washington to five-star 2028 tight end Tytan McNeal, three-star 2027 cornerback and Washington commit Maurice Willams, three-star 2027 defensive lineman Tevita Nonu and 2030 defensive lineman Tyson Daniels.

Junior Day approach

When Franklin was running the show, Junior Day had more bodies compared to what Campbell orchestrated for the first rendition of the event for him at Penn State.

There are a couple of reasons for this, with the weekend’s snow storm potentially being one of them, but the overarching point of this was to create a more intimate environment.

It allows for all the new staff to interact with targets that remain from the previous staff, meeting them for either the first or second time if recruits had an in-home or at school visit.

The same kind of approach can be said for staffers who were retained from a season ago, it gives them the same opportunity to converse with players who were looked at as Iowa State targets.

Overall, a smaller turnout allows for more face-to-face attention, and gives a feeling of being pursued more as opposed to being one of many there for the festivities.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘He’s just a Penn Stater at heart’ | An inside look at Micah Parsons’ visit to men’s hockey team
author: Chase Fisher | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State's Guy Gadowsky said on the Tengwall Film Network via YouTube on Monday that he received a call from former Nittany Lions football coach James Franklin last weekend. This call, however, wasn’t to wish him luck against then-No. 5 Wisconsin, which Penn State swept over the weekend.

It was to ask if former Nittany Lions legend, and now Green Bay Packers superstar, Micah Parsons, could come support his alma mater at the Kohl Center, where then-No. 8 Penn State and the Badgers were playing. Gadowsky, who said Parsons was a “big [Gavin] McKenna fan,” welcomed the former Penn State linebacker with open arms for their contest on Saturday.

“It was so cool to meet him,” Gadowsky said to the media on Tuesday evening. “He is such an amazing Penn Stater… He’s one of the best athletes there is. But boy does he love Penn State, and the words that he said to our team were awesome. His message was awesome. And he just so clearly loves Penn State. Believes in Penn State… And I love the message that he had for the team; it was excellent.”

Parsons visited Penn State in the locker room and talked to the team prior to and after the Nittany Lions’ win over the Badgers on Saturday. Gadowsky said he gave Parsons a time frame of around 7:05 p.m. for when the team would be coming in from warm-ups. Parsons arrived at 5 p.m., before Gadowsky was even in the locker room.

In his time with the team postgame, as after any other Penn State win, the team THOR hammer, which is given to a player who, in Gadowsky’s words on Tengwall’s live show, “fights the hardest (and) just does something spectacular for a win,” was given out.

Parsons was given the opportunity to hold it and threw it down on a table in the center of the locker room, hyping the team up as the top of the hammer flew to the opposite side of the room. Luckily, Gadowsky said the hammer was fixed.

“It was awesome,” Gadowsky said. “It was fun. It was perfect. It's not the first time (the hammer has) been broken. But that was the best time.”

It was a special moment for the players, too. Penn State’s coach said on Tengwall’s show that stars Aiden Fink and Jackson Smith, being from Calgary, are huge Green Bay Packers fans. Fink, specifically, was “jacked” to meet Parsons.

Nittany Lions captain Dane Dowiak was also pumped to see him. He remembered watching Parsons play at Beaver Stadium on his visit years ago.

“At the end of the day, he's just a Penn Stater at heart,” Dowiak said. “And I thought that was the coolest thing. And he said, through all his success throughout his career, there's no place like Penn State and wearing the blue and white. And before the game, when he told us that, I don't think anybody looked back. I think we all looked at each other and we said, ‘We're going to get this done.’ Just to have him by our side, especially when he plays in Wisconsin, having him by our side wearing that Penn State hockey jersey was really cool.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State notebook | Guy Gadowsky talks outdoor game, injury updates
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 5 Penn State is on a hot streak, winning seven of its last eight games to start 2026, just in time for arguably one of its toughest tests of the regular season.

The Nittany Lions are scheduled to host one of the top teams in the country in No. 2 Michigan State this weekend, headlined by the first-ever outdoor game at Beaver Stadium on Saturday.

Guy Gadowsky met with the media ahead of the Big Ten series to break down the outdoor game, injury updates and the Spartans.

Beaver Stadium

After the announcement back in August that Beaver Stadium would play host to its first-ever outdoor hockey game, the weekend immediately became one of the most highly anticipated series of the season.

“‘When are you guys going to play a hockey game at Beaver Stadium?’ was the most common question that I’ve had over the past 15 years,” Gadowsky said. “I didn’t think they would ever pull it off this quickly for this year, I just didn’t think it was possible.”

Penn State is set to take the ice at 1 p.m. on Saturday in front of approximately 65,000 Hockey Valley fans.

“I certainly have never played in front of 65,000 people before,” Gadowsky said. “It’s an incredible event, and shows the power of Penn State and what an incredible university it is.”

Gadowsky has continuously praised the Penn State community and the support it continues to give to the program, and his language ahead of this game was no different.

“It takes a very special institution and a very special community to pull this off, and then even more so to support it in the fashion that it’s been supported,” Gadowsky said. “(The players) are extremely excited and feel very grateful to be the ones that get a chance to do this; it’s not lost on them how special this place is.”

Injury updates

The Nittany Lions have been on the receiving end of a series of injuries over the past few weeks, and Gadowsky provided updates on two skaters.

Forward Charlie Cerrato, the team’s leading scorer at the time of his injury, exited early in Game 1 of the blue and white’s most recent series with Minnesota.

After previously classifying Cerrato’s status as “day-to-day”, Gadowsky announced on Monday that Cerrato’s injury will sideline him for the remainder of the regular season, ending with “hopefully we’ll get him back by playoffs.”

Junior Casey Aman was also injured in the same game as Cerrato, but will most likely make his return before his teammate. Gadowsky told media that the forward is still “day-to-day”, but also adding “we expect him back soon.”

Scouting of Michigan State

This is the second time the blue and white will see Michigan State, after getting swept in East Lansing back in November.

“We think that we’re a much better team now than we were back then,” Gadowsky said. “From a number of ways, and from a number of lessons, not just from that first series.”

The Spartans have been one of the top teams in the country in almost every aspect and boast one of collegiate hockey’s top goaltenders in Trey Augustine.

“Bottom line is they’re a really well-balanced team…they do everything really, really well,” Gadowsky said. “So, it’s not a matter of finding the kinks in the armor, because I don’t think that there are, it’s a matter of us playing as good and consistent a game as you can.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Position preview | Penn State softball’s pitching staff provides mix of new arms, familiar faces
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
As January reaches its end, softball season looms around the corner. Penn State is set to kick off its 2026 campaign on Feb. 6 at the NFCA Leadoff Classic in Clearwater, Florida.

The Nittany Lions finished 2025 with a 25-27 record and failed to reach a second straight NCAA Regional appearance. Last season, the blue and white were highlighted by its performance in the batter’s box, but struggled from inside the pitcher's circle.

Penn State’s staff completed last year with the highest ERA in the Big Ten at 5.76. With a highly anticipated comeback, a returning starter and new additions, the Nittany Lions have a chance to improve in the circle in 2026.

Bridget Nemeth

The 6-foot-1 junior right-hander missed a majority of the 2025 season with an injury. Nemeth’s only appearance came in the blue and white’s second game of the season against Texas Tech, in which she faced just four batters.

However, two years ago, the Glendora, California, native had a rookie campaign for the ages. In 2024, Nemeth was the Big Ten Freshman of the Year and was a unanimous First-Team All-Big Ten selection. Additionally, she was the first player in program history to be named a Freshman All-American, earning recognition by both D1 Softball and Softball America.

Nemeth finished the season with a 23-8 record, setting a program best in single-season victories. The right-hander pitched 210 innings, starting 25 of 40 appearances. Nemeth’s 1.77 ERA ranked second in the Big Ten, and her 202 strikeouts placed third.

After a year on the sidelines, Nemeth enters the upcoming season with much anticipation. If her dominant freshman campaign has any indication, it’s that the junior has the talent and poise to once again anchor the Nittany Lions’ pitching staff. Nemeth’s return could be a turning point for the blue and white, and a reminder of just how special she can be in the circle.

Abigail Britton

Britton is the lone returner from Penn State’s pitching staff last season. The sophomore right-hander split a majority of the time in the circle with the since graduated Mady Volpe. The two combined for 242.2 of the team's 316 total innings pitched.

In 2025, Britton made 42 appearances while tallying 21 starts. The LaVale, Maryland, native finished with a 6-10 record and 5.89 ERA. While Britton didn’t put up the most staggering numbers in these regards, the right-hander was best when it came to closing games out.

Britton’s five saves tied for the most in the Big Ten and already place the sophomore fifth in the Penn State record books for career saves.

Britton, now with a year of experience under her belt, will be a key part of helping the Nittany Lions improve their pitching numbers.

New faces

Along with the familiar arms in the circle, the blue and white also welcome its fair share of new ones.

Perhaps the biggest new addition to coach Clarisa Crowell’s pitching staff is South Dakota transfer McKenna Young. The junior right-hander arrives off a breakout season with the Coyotes.

Young was a Second-Team All-Summit League selection after posting a 14-8 record with a 2.46 ERA. The Broadhead, Wisconsin, native finished the season with 152 strikeouts, and her 8.3 strikeouts per seven innings ranked No. 28 nationally. Additionally, Young's five complete-game shutouts placed her at No. 31 in the country.

Penn State also welcomes a fresh crop of rookies to its rotation, which includes two-way player Gabby Gradishar, alongside left-handers Brevyn Kellepouris and Mackenzie Duncan.

Gradishar was the No. 54 prospect and No. 18 pitcher/utility player out of Champion, Ohio. She was a two-time First-Team All-State selection, as well as being named a Second-Team All-American by MaxPreps in her senior season.

Kellepouris hails from Olathe, Kansas, and was a First-Team All-State selection in her final two seasons at Olathe West High School.

Duncan arrives in Happy Valley out of Winter Garden, Florida. The 5-foot-10 left-hander was ranked as the No. 58 overall player and No. 25 pitcher by Extra Inning Softball.

With lots of new depth that includes a mix of proven experience and high-upside newcomers, Penn State enters 2026 with cautious optimism and plenty to prove in the circle. If Nemeth can return to form, Britton continues to grow into her role and the new faces find comfort quickly, the Nittany Lions have the pieces to turn last year’s biggest weakness into a strength.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Review | 7 Brew Coffee offers caffeine kick to State College
author: Lily Dorf | The Daily Collegian
description:
State College received a caffeine boost with Arkansas-based coffee and energy drink bar 7 Brew Coffee opening up at 1923 S Atherton St, this winter. The store is open from 5:30 a.m. to 10 p.m. every day, and offers coffee, energy drinks, teas and non-caffeinated options with customizations allowed for all.

This week, I ventured over to try out some of the new and exciting flavors of the various drink options.

Pixie Stick 7 Energy

I chose to order three drinks with the Pixie Stick 7 Energy being the first. The flavors within the drink help bring out the classic Pixie Stick flavor, combining orange, pomegranate and almond. I would say this drink has hints of a Pixie Stick flavor, with the orange coming out more than the other two.

My first sip tasted more like a cherry slushie, however after a few sips I started to taste the hints of orange and some slight pomegranate. The flavors within the drink are not incredibly overpowering, giving the drink a nice, balanced flavor.

Unfortunately, the Pixie Stick 7 Energy was a bit too sweet for me. If you are a fan of sweeter energy drinks, this is definitely the one for you. This drink can be customized with the original energy base or with their sugar-free option.

Rating: 7/10

Peaches N’ Cream 7 Fizz

This was the second drink I tried, opting for a non-caffeinated option to see how they compared to the caffeinated drinks offered.

The fizz drinks are made with a base of unflavored sparkling water, with syrups being added to give each drink its signature flavor.

Peaches N’ Cream is made with peach and vanilla syrups, which can be substituted for sugar-free versions as well.

The sweetness level went down with this drink compared to the first, giving it a nice and refreshing flavor palette. It had the same essence as a peach ring candy, with the vanilla syrup being hard to pinpoint within the drink.

Because of this, the flavor and overall taste of the soda were not over the top, but still present, having more flavor than other sparkling water drinks. I could see this being a very refreshing drink to grab in the heat of the summer, or something to sip on while relaxing in the sun.

Rating: 8/10

Snickerdoodle Mocha

This was the last and final drink I tried during my review, with it being the heaviest. The Snickerdoodle Mocha is a part of the store's 7 Classics, along with six other coffee-based drinks.

The drink contains a brown sugar cinnamon syrup mixed with vanilla mocha, and of course espresso. The Snickerdoodle Mocha also comes in a decaf option and has many customizations like milk type, sweetness level, toppings and sugar-free brown sugar cinnamon syrup.

The cinnamon within the drink was strong but not over the top, letting the mocha and coffee shine through. It was not extremely sweet like I had expected, which was a nice surprise. However, if you are not a big fan of mocha, I would opt for a different drink or customize the syrup.

The coffee also did not have a strong or bitter taste to it, helping to balance the drink out well. If strong coffee is what you usually go for, I would suggest asking for a lower sweetness level to your liking.

Overall, the flavors did not clash and made for a smooth and sweet drink.

Rating: 8/10

Final Thoughts

As someone who tries to steer clear of drinking too much caffeine throughout the day — whether that's energy drinks or coffee altogether — it was amazing to see so many options offered for those who are also looking to lower their caffeine intake.

With such a variety of drinks on the menu, this is an amazing spot to check out before class, on your way to a long study session or just to grab a few tasty drinks with friends.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Position preview | Penn State baseball pitchers add impact performers to staff
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
After obtaining a 33-23 overall record and reaching the Big Ten semifinals, Penn State looks to reach the postseason for a third-straight year with a promising pitching staff.

However, losing an ace to the MLB Draft in Ryan DeSanto could pose a threat to third-year head coach Mike Gambino. The skipper turned to the transfer portal in an attempt to fill a void in the starting rotation.

Starters

Gambino found a possible hidden gem in Kyle Lazer through the portal. Lazer spent four years at West Chester and joined Penn State as a redshirt senior. While transitioning from a Division II to a Division I school can be unusual, Lazer arrives off his best season by far.

The right-handed pitcher made 13 starts and earned an 8-3 record. In those 13 appearances, Lazer recorded a 3.17 ERA with 75 strikeouts in 71 innings.

While competition will surely ramp up for the Havertown, Pennsylvania, native, he has the chance to find himself a starting role and continue to produce great outings.

Frankie Sanchez looks to make his return to the rotation after being out the entirety of the 2025 season with injury. Before being injured, the right-handed pitcher threw 27 strikeouts in 37.2 innings.

The redshirt senior will have a shot to end his final collegiate season with stellar outings and continue to add to the starting rotation.

Relievers

The bullpen received a couple of additions through the portal, as well. One being Ben Hudson from West Virginia.

The right-handed pitcher saw 27.1 innings in which he recorded 30 strikeouts. Hudson didn’t allow a run in any game where he pitched more than an inning. The Medford, New Jersey, native did his part in getting the Mountaineers to the NCAA Super Regionals.

Of the returning arms, Matthew VanOstenbridge looks to continue to produce for the bullpen after making 23 appearances in his freshman year. The southpaw recorded a 4.32 ERA, striking out 38 in 41.2 innings.

VanOstenbridge will continue to be a hot arm out of the bullpen.

Similar to Sanchez, Ben DeMell enters his final collegiate season as a redshirt senior after a promising 2025 season. The right-handed pitcher brought his ERA down to 4.65 after doubling his previous strikeout total to 43.

The Concord, Ohio, native brings a towering figure at 6-foot-5 and 205 pounds, a size that could shake batters as they will be awaiting strong and fast pitches from the mound.

From dipping into the transfer portal to returning arms in the bullpen, Gambino sets his pitching room up in hopes of making it further than the semifinals in the Big Ten tournament.

MORE BASEBALL COVERAGE

title: How to revamp your wardrobe using clothes you already own
author: Lexi Cannan | The Daily Collegian
description:
January rolls around and suddenly nothing in your closet makes sense. Everyone has fresh outfits after break, and your closet didn’t get the memo. You’re standing there wondering how a full closet turned into absolutely nothing to wear.

It’s the same hoodies, jeans and jackets — nothing’s different, it just suddenly feels old. The good news is you don’t need to go shopping to fix it.

A closet reset usually isn’t about buying new clothes, it’s about noticing the ones you already have. Most of the time, they’ve just faded into the background.

Dress for your real day

It’s easy to keep clothes for a version of yourself that doesn’t really exist. Outfits for plans you never make, pieces that only work if you’re suddenly a morning person or the clothes that looked good once but don’t fit your day-to-day anymore can all be discarded.

Dress for your real schedule, not the one you swear you’ll have “next week.” Long walks to class, lecture halls, quick food and unpredictable weather don’t need complicated outfits. They require clothes that feel comfortable, easy and reliable.

When your clothes actually fit your routine, getting dressed stops feeling like a daily struggle and just happens.

Rotate what’s in front

If you see the same five things every morning, surprise, that’s all you’re wearing. A closet reset can be as simple as “oh wait, I forgot I owned this.” Sometimes all it takes is moving one thing to the front for it to feel new again.

Most mornings are rushed. You’re just trying to get to class on time, grab coffee and remember what’s due, not plan an outfit.

When you’re half awake, you grab whatever’s easiest. That’s why the same stuff’s on repeat, not because the rest doesn’t work.

Changing what’s in front breaks that pattern. A few little changes can stop you from grabbing the same thing without thinking.

Stop saving outfits for “someday”

A lot of clothes sit untouched because they’re being saved for the “right occasion.” The problem is this imaginary event almost never happens, and if it does, you’ll probably end up wearing something else anyway.

College life is mostly made up of regular days. Classes, studying, quick plans and walking across campus don’t exactly scream “special occasion.” Those are the days you’re actually living.

If you like something, wear it now. Don’t save it for a night that may or may not come, or a plan that might get canceled at the last minute. Clothes don’t need to be a big moment, they just need a reason to leave your closet.

Worst case, you wear it to class and nothing happens. Best case, you feel a little more put together on a very normal day. Honestly, that’s a win.

Let comfort do the work

A good outfit doesn’t need to be impressive. It just needs to feel good enough that you’re not thinking about it all day or constantly adjusting it between classes.

Jeans that fit well, hoodies that don’t itch and shoes you can actually walk across campus in matter way more than trends. When you’re comfortable, you’re not distracted by what you’re wearing, and that confidence shows — even on days when just getting dressed feels like enough.

If you’re fixing your clothes all day, they’re not doing their job. Comfort matters when your days are long and you’re always on the move. The best outfits are the ones you forget you’re even wearing.

Outfit repeating is allowed

Wearing a jacket twice in one week? That’s normal behavior. It’s kind of impressive you didn’t lose it between classes or leave it on a chair somewhere.

If it makes mornings easier, it earns a repeat. Most people aren’t paying attention to what you’re wearing , they’re focused on getting through their own chaos, making it to class on time and remembering when their next exam is.

Outfit repetition is the least of anyone’s concerns. If it makes your day easier, that’s all it really needs to do.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Satire | TikTok’s new terms of service are just fine, actually
author: Jadzia Santiago | The Daily Collegian
description:
So, you’ve read TikTok’s new terms of service. Or, rather, you opened the app and hit “Agree”, only to look at the news three hours later and read that (allegedly) you just sold everything but your soul for your 8 a.m. dose of hopelessness and hot influencers.

That didn’t faze you at first. As someone who’s terminally online, you’re no stranger to making problems for yourself.

But now that sale (also allegedly) has sociopolitical implications?

I mean, they’re tracking information “you disclose” about your “racial or ethnic origin, national origin, religious beliefs, mental or physical health diagnosis, sexual life or sexual orientation, status as transgender or nonbinary, citizenship or immigration status, or financial information,” ehhh macarena.

Sounds like a lot, and feels a little relevant. Well, doomscrollers rejoice, because this really isn’t that big a deal!

First off, as your local tinfoil hat would argue, it’s nothing that Big Tech wasn’t doing anyway. Anyone familiar with the demonic wiles of 5G (and the terms and conditions of other social media apps) knows just how much information They take from you anyway.

Now they’re just being open about it, which isn’t worrying at all. Privacy, in the digital age? Pssssh.

And besides, best case scenario is that they’re using that data for, you guessed it, ads!

All they wanna do is sell you solutions to your deepest insecurities and darkest fears.

Acne? There’s an unregulated supplement with no ingredient list for that. Stomach fat? Brutal shapewear that crushes your lungs. All followed by 20 videos about how unlovable those traits are, so you gotta get rid of them stat.

Speaking of love, are you worried about coming out to your parents (because you may not know how many times you watched that thirst trap, but your data does)? Don’t worry, they’ll send more and more ads for pride merch to the family TV!

Never worry about being homesick again, because having someone to strategically gather your secrets and use them against you will make you feel like you’re always with your family.

Who needs to use that information for something like diagnosing health conditions when you can sell it?

All harmless — of course, unless you’re starting to develop the Wrong Opinions. And they can tell when you are, you know.

But like, with an all-seeing presence devoted to moral goodness like this, how could you ever go wrong in life? When not even your step count or your resting heart rate are yours anymore, it feels a little like having a guardian angel.

Considering how lonely we all are right now, I think we need a companion. And the algorithm might just be the snuggliest machine gun the world has ever seen.

Come on, not even your boyfriend listens to you this much.

Even if the government really is collecting your data to use it for who knows what, that doesn’t matter. Don’t you know that your seasonal allergies, tarot cards, celebrity crushes and pronouns are all matters of national security?

Forget anything else, you, the little nerd scrolling through fan edits of Joe Keery and Maya Hawke in “Stranger Things” should be our biggest priority as a nation.

Maybe it’ll make you a little nervous if you’re politically outspoken, but we live in a democracy with freedom of speech, so that shouldn’t be an issue … right?

Anyway! All in all, these open, honest changes to TikTok really make me hopeful for the future. Years from now, I can still see myself opening the app for a dopamine hit when the real world becomes just too much.

And one day, when the algorithm notices I’m spending .0002 seconds too long watching another woman’s makeup tutorial, they’ll set to work to protect the streets from my moral poison.

Onto my friends’ feeds will come a slew of posts on How to Spot Female Narcissists and Energy Vampires, top traits being Has opinions, thoughts and feelings and Wants to hang out occasionally.

The solution? Grab your essential oils and cut her off, girlfriend! And just when I’m isolated enough to have no character witnesses, they’ll put me in front of the almighty Thought Crimes tribunal.

There, ChatGPT will convict me of the capital crimes of vanity, envy and lust before sentencing me to the Grok-powered death ray that, because I’m a woman, will only vaporize my clothes. #FeministOwned.

MORE COLUMNS

title: Taking the biggest stage | Nicole Hall represents Penn State women’s hockey at Olympics
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Surrounded by her teammates, sophomore Nicole Hall received the call of a lifetime with an invitation to the 2026 Olympic Games.

“One of the teammates filmed her getting the call from the Swedish officials, and it was just pure joy on her face and her reaction,” coach Jeff Kampersal told The Daily Collegian. “It’s a pretty genuine response, and I’m proud of her for putting in the time.”

While only a sophomore at Penn State, Hall experienced international play well before she takes on the Olympics in February.

The Stockholm, Sweden, native competed on a pair of teams in the Swedish Women’s Hockey League before representing her country on the 18U Swedish team at the 2021 and 2022 World Championships.

When Hall arrived at Penn State in 2024, she already had six years of international and semi-professional experience.

“She’s such a great teammate,” sophomore Abby Stonehouse said. “She’s super fun to be around, helps her teammates out, and then on the ice, is obviously a great player, high hockey IQ and makes her line mates better.”

Right off the bat, Hall took the ice for the Nittany Lions and her presence had a positive influence on her team.

While playing in all 38 games in her freshman year, Hall recorded seven goals and four assists. Just two weeks into the season, the forward recorded her first and second career goals in back-to-back games against Union and Dartmouth.

“All the practices, the games, (work) off the ice, on the ice has helped me,” Hall said. “The coaches are willing to help all day, and my teammates are making me a better hockey player every day.”

As a freshman, Hall stood up and helped her teammates down the stretch of a successful season as the Nittany Lions earned a spot in the AHA semifinals against RIT.

“I watched her in the world championships when she was the captain of the U18 Sweden team,” Kampersal said. “She made it with those little things like winning plays, having good habits and being a good teammate. We knew she had leadership capabilities.”

Hall’s success was on display throughout the postseason as she recorded two blocks and a faceoff victory as she wrapped up her first year as an AHA champion.

Entering her second season, Hall’s efforts were even more on display as she increased her work ethic and put in the work ahead of Year 2.

“(The biggest thing I learned from her) is how hard she works,” Stonehouse said. “She never takes a shift off. She’s always in there, so she just taught me to always keep my feet moving and work hard.”

Just as the Nittany Lions opened 2025 with success — earning 16 straight wins — Hall found her own success with goals in each of the first two games of the year.

“Nicole and her teammates kind of run the show in terms of how they want their season to go,” Kampersal said. “She just brings that lunch pail, work hard mentality to Penn State.”

After 16 straight wins, Penn State suffered its first loss of the season against Northeastern on Nov. 28. With the help of Hall’s mentality, the blue and white came back and went on an 8-3 stretch since then.

“Sometimes you can get frustrated a bit, but she just keeps up the positive energy,” graduate student Mya Vaslet said. “She just keeps saying, ‘Just trust the process, it’ll come,’ and I think that’s really important too.”

On Jan. 12, Hall received a phone call from the Swedish national team, giving her the news that she would be competing in her first Olympic Games.

“We were all really excited,” Vaslet said. “I know she was waiting to get the call, but there wasn’t a doubt in any of our minds she wasn’t going to get it.”

While Hall has played for the senior women’s team in 15 contests, February will mark her first time suiting up for the Olympic Games, a memory she’ll never forget.

“I started crying right away when they told me I have a ticket for the Olympics,” Hall said. “I was speechless, I didn’t know what to say.”

In addition to Hall taking the big stage, her teammates Matilde Fantin, Tessa Janecke and former Nittany Lion Jessica Adolfsson will all compete in the Olympics as well.

“No matter (what position) you play at Penn State hockey, we get better day in and day out,” Vaslet said. “It shows with people going to the Olympics.”

After competing in their first preliminary contest on Feb. 5 against Germany, Hall and Team Sweden will face off against Fantin and Team Italy on Feb. 7.

“Let the best woman win,” Hall said.

MORE HOCKEY CONTENT

title: Position preview | Penn State softball brings in young outfielders
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State’s 2026 season is rapidly approaching, with its season opener in the near future. The Nittany Lions are poised for a bounce-back year after finishing 25-27 and missing the NCAA tournament in 2025.

While the blue and white have a plethora of returners on the infield, its outfield will be filled with mostly fresh faces in the new campaign. After the pair of veteran outfielders, Jenna Nelson and Haylie Brunson, graduated, Clarisa Crowell’s squad is left with two open positions in the outfield.

Sophomore Natalie Lieto spearheads the outfield as the lone returner this season for the Nittany Lions, while junior Frankee Flesher and freshman Breanna Hanik are set for their first seasons.

Natalie Lieto

The Monroe, Connecticut, native had a breakout freshman campaign on both sides of the field last season. Lieto brings experience as she started all 50 games she played in, slashing an impressive .329 batting average, with seven home runs and 30 RBIs in 149 at bats. Her 49 hits were fifth-most on the team in Penn State’s historic 2025 offensive campaign.

The 5-foot-7 outfielder also flashed the glove, surrendering just one error and finishing with an outstanding 0.990 fielding percentage. Lieto’s lockdown defense didn’t go unnoticed, as she was one of just two true freshmen to be named to the Big Ten All-Defensive Team.

Lieto also reached base often with an efficient .936 OPS and was sneaky on the basepaths, stealing 10 bases in 12 attempts.

Penn State must continue to get this production and more from its star outfielder in Lieto’s sophomore campaign. She’s essential for anchoring the defense in the outfield alongside two rookie players.

Frankee Flesher

The Chesterland, Ohio, native enters her first collegiate softball season after she joined the program following the conclusion of the 2025 season. The junior was previously a member of the women’s soccer team before medically retiring from the sport.

Flesher brings two years of varsity softball experience at West Gauga High School and a few years of travel experience with the Ohio Outlaws 05 National program from 2019 to 2021 into Happy Valley. As a standout soccer player in high school, she is versatile and extremely athletic, allowing her to be spread out across the outfield.

The 5-foot-5 outfielder’s last softball season was outstanding. As a sophomore at West Gauga High School, the lefty batter produced a .629 average with 39 hits and 22 RBIs.

Breanna Hanik

The Oak Lawn, Illinois, native was a standout recruit in the 2025 class, ranked as the nation’s No. 65 overall player and No. 22 among outfielders. Hanik led Marist High School to the state championship game in three seasons throughout her four years and was named an All-Conference choice in 2023 and 2024.

Her breakout junior campaign earned her All-State, All-Area and Golden Glove awards, and she also set a single-season doubles record with 19. Hanik is the whole package of speed, power, and defense, recording 11 home runs and 16 stolen bases in one season.

With young players throughout the outfield and playing together for the first time, Crowell may switch around their positions during the season. The fresh talent brings much to look forward to on both sides of the field for the blue and white’s faithful fans.

MORE SOFTBALL CONTENT

title: 'She’s got incredible drive’ | Janecke’s path to becoming Penn State women’s hockey’s first US Olympian
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
One player stands alone at the pinnacle of Hockey Valley.

Tessa Janecke has tallied 193 points and counting across four seasons, led the Nittany Lions to three-consecutive AHA championships and is now headed overseas to play for the United States Women’s Ice Hockey Team in the upcoming 2026 Milano-Cortina Winter Olympic Games.

Janecke, the team's captain, is Penn State’s program leader in points and goals. She recently played her last regular-season series with the blue and white before her break from collegiate action to compete against her teammates, Nicole Hall (Sweden) and Matilde Fantin (Italy), in the most prestigious tournament in concurrent sports history.

“It's always an honor to get to throw on your flag,” Janecke said. “To be able to take in that moment and appreciate what's led you to that moment, and have appreciation for Penn State and my teammates and teammates in the past as well.”

Janecke is the first Penn State ice hockey player to compete on behalf of the United States in the Olympic Games. Prior to Milano-Cortina, the lone Penn Stater to appear in the games was Sweden’s Jessica Adolfsson, who’ll be returning to international action to play alongside Hall and face her fellow Nittany Lions.

From the moment Janecke stepped into the locker room at Pegula Ice Arena, coach Jeff Kampersal said he noticed one thing — her innate drive to win.

“(Janecke’s) got incredible drive and she also has a mean streak, too,” Kampersal said. So, if you look at Tessa or Abbey Murphy from Minnesota, those kids can stay by you. They can run you over, and they're driven towards their goals, whether it's making the Olympics or it's trying to win a national championship.”

Among the many Olympic rosters are a mix of professional talent from the Professional Women’s Hockey League (PWHL), top-tier collegiate players and veterans of international competition, making the Olympics the truest form of “best-on-best” hockey.

“People only see a fraction of the work that (Janecke) puts in, that our team puts in, so for her to go out there knowing that this was her dream, there's no way you can put it into words,” Katelyn Roberts said. “As a friend, I'm proud. As her teammate, I'm proud. As a watcher of hers, I'm proud. There's no other way to say it.”

Janecke isn’t merely a face amongst the many other superstars; she’s carved a legacy of her own.

With the U.S. National Team, Janecke is a two-time IIHF Women’s World Champion and one-time runner-up, winning her first in 2023 and most recently in 2025, with a silver medal in 2024 between the victories.

She also earned a silver medal in the 2022 IIHF U18 Women’s World Junior Championship.

Last April in Czechia, Janecke tapped in the “golden goal” on a backdoor feed from the Minnesota Frost’s Taylor Heise with 2:53 remaining in overtime to win the 2025 IIHF Women’s World Championship, 4-3, over Canada. Before her teammates swarmed her in celebration, Janecke leapt into the air and hoisted her stick into the stands.

“Those are not only huge moments for (Janecke), which we're proud of her for, but also, they put our program on the map,” Roberts said. “She is such a talented player, and we were so lucky to have her come here. It’s a testament to the amount of skill that our team has and also how much the program has changed under coach Jeff, especially over the past couple of years, with him being able to bring in that top-caliber talent.”

In 2023, Janecke scored three goals and added three helpers throughout the tournament to aid the United States in winning the gold medal against the hosting nation, Canada.

“(The Olympics are) going to be on a much bigger scale,” Janecke said. “There are a lot more eyes on you, but I think for our team, nothing is going to change. We’ve got to go in there with the right mindset, but there can't be a moment that's going to be too big or one that we're not prepared for.”

Janecke is currently riding the high of a 40-point season with the Nittany Lions, including an eight-game point streak. She leads Penn State with 19 goals and 21 assists heading into her break in action from the NCAA.

On the national scale this season, Janecke ranks ninth in points and eighth in goals. That includes her missing a few games due to her playing in the 2025 Rivalry Series, a four-game showcase against Team Canada that the United States swept. There, Janecke tallied a goal and two assists.

“It's definitely posed more as an opportunity than a loss because it's an amazing opportunity for (Janecke), and there's no way she should pass this up,” Roberts said. “For us, we kind of see it as an opportunity for our forwards to grow and to gain depth for our team, so that when she does come back, we're in a groove scoring and she'll be in her groove scoring, and all the pieces will fit together at the right time.”

Despite having to miss collegiate action for a month in Europe, Janecke’s senior season isn’t over yet. With the AHA and NCAA tournaments waiting for her when she returns to Happy Valley, the captain has one more chance to secure the coveted National Championship with her alma mater.

“Maybe we're not as formidable without Tessa, Nicole and Matilde, but we're still pretty deep, and we're still going to show up and play hard,” Kampersal said. “And I think our players want to prove that they can do it without those three players as well. When they come back, they'll be even stronger.”

Having already left campus for training camps, Janecke will be missing the rest of the regular season as well as the first round of the upcoming AHA playoffs. This includes Penn State’s first-ever outdoor game at Beaver Stadium against Robert Morris.

“I'm going to be missing games, but I have confidence in our team that they're going to be just fine without me,” Janecke said. “And honestly, I think they'll play even harder knowing that I'm gone as well.”

MORE HOCKEY CONTENT

title: Position preview | Penn State men’s lacrosse’s faceoff guys, goalies combine for little experience
author: AJ Piazza | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State men’s lacrosse will have a change at the goaltending position. Longtime goalie Jack Fracyon has moved on to the PLL, meaning there will be a goalkeeper in the crease. The same can’t be said for the Nittany Lions in the faceoff circle.

The blue and white have a few returners and should be more stable than last season.

Faceoff Guys

A big surprise last season was Colby Baldwin. Baldwin was crucial on the faceoff dot. Baldwin led the team in attempts with 269 and won 156 of those draws for a .580 faceoff win percentage. That was a large increase from his freshman season, where he only had a .379 faceoff winning percentage that first year.

The junior also contributed three goals and four assists. The White Plains, New York, native will be crucial in getting the Nittany Lions' possession to start the offense in each game.

Competing with Baldwin is Reid Gills. The sophomore took draws after Baldwin got injured. Gills went 79-for-130, which is a .608 faceoff win percentage. There could be some competition between the two, but it’s likely Baldwin will get the start. Gills will be the main backup and will play if Baldwin struggles.

Zach Arbuckle rounds out the faceoff guys on the roster. Arbuckle was a three-star recruit according to Inside Lacrosse. He could see the field if an injury were to occur, but it’s expected that he redshirts.

Goalies

With the loss of Fracyon, Ben Johnson is in line to be the starter. Johnson is also the only goaltender on the roster who has played in a game. The Peoria, Illinois, native has played in five total games, including two from last season, tallying three saves and a .600 save percentage last season.

Johnson has a goals against average of 8.00, but only faced a total of eight shots last year. This will be the first time he has a strong chance to have the crease to himself.

Preston Hawkins is a potential backup. Hawkins was the 96th best player in the 2025 recruiting class and could be given a chance to flash his skill if the squad is dominating a game.

With the lack of playing experience behind Johnson, it seems that Hawkins is the frontrunner to be the backup.

The other depth in the cage are Will Mitchell and Hayes Schreiner. Mitchell redshirted last season, and Schreiner hasn’t seen the field in three years with the squad.

It seems that both are desperate depth options, but neither is expected to see the field next season.

MORE LACROSSE CONTENT

title: Breaking down Marcus Blaze’s competition at 133 pounds for potential postseason run
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
Marcus Blaze entered Happy Valley as the No. 1 wrestler in the 2025 recruiting class. Before even wrestling in a blue and white singlet, Blaze took the international world by storm.

He’s a U17 and U20 World Champion, placed third at the 2024 Olympic Trials as an 18-year old and owns four state championships in Ohio. He left Perrysburg High School with a 196-2 record.

All of those accolades made it seem like Blaze would be a contender for the national title, no matter the weight class he was in. Blaze is currently No. 4 in the national rankings, but the competition at 133 pounds continues to get deeper and deeper following the potential burning of multiple redshirts.

To begin, the national finalists last year — Lucas Byrd of Illinois and Iowa’s Drake Ayala — are back for another year. To emphasize the depth of this weight class, Ayala, who’s been on the verge of a national title for the past couple years, is No. 9 in the country, according to InterMat.

Ohio State redshirt freshman Ben Davino has been unleashed for the Buckeyes and is a big reason for them being No. 2 in the NWCA rankings. Davino holds a 15-0 record and could pose as the biggest threat to Blaze’s undefeated dual season when Ohio State travels to the Bryce Jordan Center in February.

The other Big Ten competitor is Zan Fugitt out of Wisconsin. Fugitt ranks at No. 12 and adds to the young crop of talent. Fugitt is a redshirt sophomore and placed fourth at the NCAA Tournament last season in his first full season of competition.

Out of the Big 12, No. 3 Evan Frost from Iowa State appears to be the favorite for the conference title with Arizona State’s Kyler Larkin not far behind him at No. 6 with a 14-1 record. Frost didn’t wrestle against the Sun Devils when the Cyclones defeated them 29-14 on Jan. 6.

Behind them is Dominick Sorrano, who holds a 9-0 record out of Northern Colorado.

Despite the three Big 12 wrestlers, and Big Ten wrestlers who could all earn the national title spot, there’s two new freshmen that are expected to burn their redshirts and will instantly become contenders.

Oklahoma State no longer has a problem at 133 pounds after Jax Forrest enrolled early with the Cowboys. Forrest was a 2025 U23 World Champion, as well as a 2025 US Open champion.

Forrest instantly becomes a favorite for the national title, and a Blaze-Forrest title match would likely break the internet. It’d be the first time Cael Sanderson and David Taylor sat across from each other at the biggest stage, and for it to be two of the best young stars in the sport facing off, the hype for the matchup would be palpable.

The other freshman who’s expected to burn his redshirt is Virginia Tech’s Aaron Seidel. In his most recent match, Seidel took down then-No. 7 Tyler Knox of Stanford, 13-0. In one of his first matches of his young career, Seidel took down Dylan Shawver, the 2024 Big Ten Champion, by tech fall, solidifying his arrival onto the scene.

With Forrest and Seidel’s emergence, in addition to the other major competitors, the 133-pound weight class could cause chaos come NCAA Tournament time, making Blaze’s path to the final a tough task.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Exploring Penn State women’s basketball’s 5 worst seasons in history
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is in the midst of one of its worst seasons in program history, currently riding a 10-game losing streak.

While the Lady Lions’ longest losing stretch sits at 15 games in coach Carolyn Kieger’s first season in 2019, this year’s team is on track to reach that historic low.

The blue and white has experienced 11 losing seasons over the past 20 years.

8 straight losses: 2021-22

While Penn State didn’t reach a double-digit losing streak in the 2021-22 season, it still experienced another losing season behind Kieger.

Coming back from the COVID-19 pandemic, junior Makenna Marisa played in peak form, averaging 22.2 points on the year. However, the Lady Lions lost five games by single digits and got blown out by over 20 points in another six games.

Penn State moved through nonconference play with a 6-5 record before going 3-3 to start the Big Ten season.

From there, the Lady Lions lost eight straight games before winning three games and dropping another two to end the year.

10 straight losses: 2024-25

After losing eight players to graduation and the transfer portal, many expected the 2024-25 season would likely be a down year for the Lady Lions.

Through the first eight games of the year, that didn’t seem to be an issue as Penn State went 8-0 with wins over Duquesne and Georgia. However, the blue and white’s struggles began in its final win of that stretch, struggling in an overtime victory against Drexel.

The Lady Lions dropped the next two games before winning against Providence and losing seven straight to open conference play.

After upsetting No. 9 Ohio State for its only Big Ten win of the year, Penn State lost the next ten straight and missed out on the Big Ten tournament for the first time in program history.

10 straight losses (and counting): 2025-26

This year saw even more players depart Penn State, with seven players entering the transfer portal and three graduating.

Despite bringing in former Rutgers standout Kiyomi McMiller and a group of talented freshmen, Kieger’s squad has struggled in what it believed could be an NCAA tournament-bound year.

Through 21 games, the Lady Lions remain winless in conference play and are on a 10-game losing streak.

While Gracie Merkle and McMiller sit at fifth and sixth in the conference in scoring, the rest of the team has yet to find an answer as Penn State’s losing streak continues and its possibilities of a Big Ten tournament appearance grow slimmer.

12 straight losses: 2007-08

Penn State’s second-worst stretch of all time came amidst another coaching change, as the reins were handed from Rene Portland to Coquese Washington in 2007.

The Lady Lions succeeded early in Washington’s premiere season, winning three straight, including an upset of No. 20 Pitt.

Less than a month later, the blue and white caused another upset over No. 10 Duke to end the nonconference schedule with a 9-3 record.

Penn State opened its Big Ten season with a 4-3 start before losing 12 straight to end the year, despite only two games coming against ranked opponents.

15 straight losses: 2019-20

Kieger’s first season at Penn State showed the Happy Valley faithful a glimpse of what was to come throughout her career — lots of losses.

The Marquette alum opened her Lady Lion career with a 7-23 season, experiencing 15 straight losses in the final two months of action.

While Penn State earned wins against Towson, Fordham, Clemson and Pitt to start the season, it also fell to several mid-major teams, including Rider, La Salle and Long Beach State.

The Lady Lions came out victorious in their first conference matchup of the year against Michigan State before falling in 15 straight matchups to end the season, including their first-round contest in the Big Ten tournament.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘I still need to realize it’s actually real’ | Matilde Fantin’s journey to the Olympic stage
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
Matilde Fantin has spent the last few months traveling from Penn State to Italy’s Olympic camp in Canada, gearing up daily for early-morning skates and playing in multiple games in hopes of achieving a childhood dream.

Following months of preparation, the freshman can now call herself an Olympian.

“I still need to realize it’s actually real,” Fantin told The Daily Collegian. “I’m really happy, and I’m excited to show how good (Team Italy) is. I’m excited to represent my country again.”

The Como, Italy, native’s path to reaching the Olympics has been nothing short of impressive. Before making her start at Penn State, Fantin had the honor to represent her country at the 2025 IIHF Division 1B Women’s World Championship. She used this monumental stage to showcase her talent, leading the tournament with 10 points.

The skills shown by Fantin stood out to coach Jeff Kampersal in his recruiting process, leading to one of the most impactful additions to the lineup.

“Matilde is a hard worker. She looks like a pro and has a pro skill set in the way that she plays with her head up,” Kampersal said. “She does a lot of good things, like creating time and space. She's really smart. She takes instructions, so she shows a willingness to get better.”

Fantin adjusted quickly to collegiate hockey, as she has already won multiple AHA conference awards. Most notably, being the Freshman of the Month in September and October.

More than halfway through her freshman season, the forward showed her willingness to learn through her on-ice training with upperclassmen. As a result, Fantin believes that playing for Penn State has been a great place for her to “play and grow.”

“I think just having the chance to go on the ice with really good players and training with them,” Fantin said. “Also, having the chance to experience playing with Tessa (Janecke) and some of the seniors is just great. It's a great environment to grow.”

Off the ice, Fantin has found a connection with fellow international freshman, Danica Maynard. The Lake Country, British Columbia, native has been beside Fantin every step of the way on and off the ice.

“(Fantin and I) understand each other, and we understand that we may be missing home sometimes and we can’t contact (our families),” Maynard said. “Just being able to look out for each other, that’s a really good spot for us. We never feel alone.”

Fantin said she’s leaned heavily on herself for support over the past few months.

“Just feeling good about myself and having my confidence up. It's always hard, especially when you see other people that are fighting for a spot, and you're in the same situation,” Fantin said. “Just keep the focus up and having my confidence up, I just keep going every day. Working hard.”

Though hockey isn’t a popular sport in Italy, Fantin said that didn't deter her.

“Hockey is not really important for our nation, so it’s always hard to get a chance to play in college and showcase yourself,” Fantin said. “I would just say to my younger self to keep working hard and going with your passion, hockey is the thing I love to do.”

As the games quickly approach, starting on Feb. 5, the freshman is excited about the state of the women’s hockey program at Penn State. The program is home to four total Olympians.

Fantin will join two current Penn State teammates, Janecke and Nicole Hall, as the three Nittany Lions represent their respective countries in the games. Jessica Adolfsson, a defenseman for Penn State from 2018 to 2021, fills out the Nittany Lions represented abroad.

“I’m really happy for (Janecke and Hall) making the team. It just shows how good of a program we are right now,” Fantin said. “I think it’s great that players from our school can represent, as well.”

title: Severe Penn State winter weather through the Collegian’s lens
author: Kiera Ginn | The Daily Collegian
description:
State College received around 12.6 inches of snow over the weekend, resulting in the cancellation of Monday’s classes and activities. The town is no stranger to snow, here’s a look at how large accumulations of snow impacted Penn State over the years through the Collegian’s lens.

1951

A snowstorm occurred during what many predicted to be a mild winter, based on an old wives tale about the thickness of the stripes on a caterpillar’s back foretelling the severity of the upcoming winter.

Despite the tale, State College received over six inches of snow on Dec. 15, 1951, days before the official start of winter on Dec. 21.

1960

A storm produced ten inches of snow on Feb. 20, 1960, bringing down trees and powerlines. The snow clung with “unusual depth,” according to Collegian archives.

State police reported Centre County roads were in “bad shape” by the end of the storm, and many side roads were closed because of drifting snow. The storm was “the most wide-spread of the winter,” with four reported deaths in Pennsylvania, according to the Collegian reporting.

Less than two weeks later, on March 4, the entire Commonwealth of Pennsylvania saw between eight to 15 inches of snow. Around a foot was recorded in the borough of State College.

1961

After a record setting 64 inches of snow fall by early February, the university and the borough of State College faced budgetary constraints for snow removal.

Penn State set aside $14,000 for snow removal for the entire winter, and spent $19,000 by Feb. 8.

1993

In 1993 a rare March blizzard blanketed State College as students returned to campus after spring break. Many scrambled for shelter, and hotels filled fast around Pennsylvania as conditions became “impassable,” according to Collegian reporting.

In total, 27.5 inches of snow was recorded between March 12-14, causing the storm to be nicknamed the “Storm of Century” by the State College office of the National Weather Service.

1995

In 1992, a Nov. 16. snowstorm brought wet, heavy snow to State College, weighing heavily on trees and power lines. An OPP employee described the day as a “hazardous situation,” according to Collegian reporting.

1999

Snow and ice led to the cancellation of classes and CATA Bus services on Jan. 14. Preparations for snow removal operations were laid out by OPP to clear 23 miles of sidewalks and 31 miles of streets on the University Park campus.

A couple months later, on March 15, Students returning to State College after spring break ran into winter weather that included five inches of snow which created significant travel impacts with up to a foot of snow in surrounding states.

2002

The University Weather Service predicted around three inches of snow would greet students upon return for the spring semester on Jan. 7. Instead, 13 inches fell, which was the largest snow storm recorded since 1996, according to Collegian reporting. The weather resulted in a delay of the start of the semester.

Essential university personnel were called in as the university was closed due to winter weather in early February. If staff felt unsafe to travel, Penn State encouraged them to stay home; however, they would have to utilize personal or vacation days.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: Film review | What do new defensive line transfers bring to Penn State?
author: Avery Hill | Football Editor
description:
Penn State’s defensive line room is now the responsibility of two position coaches: defensive line coach Ikaika Malloe and edge rushers coach Christian Smith.

Doing so, Penn State secured seven new defensive linemen to bolster Penn State’s front line.

The new defensive linemen are: Iowa State’s Ike Ezeogu and Alijah Carnell; UCLA’s Keanu Williams and Siale Taupaki; Colorado’s Alexander McPherson; Utah’s Dallas Vakalahi; and Oklahoma State’s Armstrong Nnodim.

With many things in common among the group, here’s a look at a few things that define the newcomers.

Size

One thing was clear from the moment Malloe was hired — the Nittany Lions were going to get bigger.

The heaviest of the listed players is the 6-foot-5 Williams, who’s listed at 320 pounds. Taupaki and Vakalahi aren’t too far behind at 6-foot-2, 310 pounds and 6-foot-2, 318 pounds, respectively.

Size, size, size 🥩:New DL coach Ikaika Malloe added some beef up front in UCLA’s Keanu Williams and Siale TaupakiHere’s the 310-pound Taupaki jumping on a fumble pic.twitter.com/3eWDPR4P2x— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 28, 2026

The enormous trio brings girth Penn State hasn’t had on its defensive front since PJ Mustipher, who was listed at 6-foot-4, 326 pounds in 2021. Nnodim fills out his 6-foot-2, 290-pound frame well, and could see more growth in Happy Valley.

Even in Smith’s section, McPherson and Ezeogu provide size at 6-foot-6, 240 pounds and 6-foot-5, 285 pounds, respectively.

McPherson could also become a weapon for special teams coordinator Justin Lustig, as he blocked a punt against Delaware last season.

Even on the edge, in comes 6-foot-6 Colorado transfer Alexander McPherson.His highlight play in 2025 was a punt block against Delaware.The six-foot-5 DE Dani Dennis-Sutton notably blocked three punts for Penn State last season pic.twitter.com/U1siPzZO9M— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 28, 2026

At 6-foot-5, 290 pounds, Carnell could play both on the interior and on the edge. He spread his playing time between nose tackle, defensive tackle and at defensive end last season.

Run support

Outside of the former Cyclones, all of the new transfers played in run defenses ranked in the bottom half of their respective conferences. Still, with their size being a key factor, they could help a Penn State run defense that was ranked 11th in the Big Ten at 142.3 yards allowed per game.

The one that likely boasts the highest expectations in that category going into 2026 is Williams. The redshirt senior registered 13 run stops and totaled 39 tackles in 2025, receiving a 68.3 run defense grade from Pro Football Focus.

Ground shutdown ❌: The 320-pound Williams has the size and strength to fit into any menacing run defense.Williams not just shed the block, but hustled down the line for a nice finish on the running back early against USC pic.twitter.com/ZRLiVZzR6E— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 28, 2026

Williams is strong enough to command his gap responsibilities, and once he gets to the running back, they typically have nowhere to go. He played in new defensive coordinator D’Anton Lynn’s UCLA defense in 2023, earning a 73.9 Pro Football Focus run grade in 111 run defense snaps.

Vakalahi and Taupaki also naturally slot in as good fits to be two-gappers in Lynn’s scheme. In run situations, throwing either of the two on the inside beside Williams should boast quality results.

McPherson finished 21st at Colorado in snaps on run defense, so it'll be interesting to see how much he sees the field in run situations.

McPherson easily read his key before running down the line of scrimmage for a run stop on this one. He was still used sparingly in Colorado’s run defense pic.twitter.com/G8KcHhTT5x— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 28, 2026

Pass rush

While Penn State’s run defense should have the depth to compete with ground-heavy programs throughout the game, it didn’t bring in much help to rush the passer.

The biggest add in terms of rushers was McPherson, who totaled 10 pressures and drew interest from programs like Vanderbilt, Ole Miss and Auburn after his true freshman season. His size paired with quality hands gives him a chance to take a big jump in 2026.

But behind him in terms of skillset among new edge rushers is Ezeogu, who had 14 pressures in 2025. He had one of the worst pass-rush win rates in the country at 4.3%.

To rush or to not rush 🤔:There aren’t many sacks to come by from any of the new additions, but one with the best track record is Ezeogu, who had 14 pressures in 2025Here’s an Ezeogu sack from a couple of seasons ago pic.twitter.com/9gwR0vvIC2— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 28, 2026

On the interior, just Taupaki stood out rushing the passer in 2025, finishing second on a struggling Bruins’ unit with nine pressures while also tallying a sack.

Taupaki played in 66 less pass-rush snaps than Williams, but he made it count.Taupaki was second on the Bruins in pressure with nine, and notched a sack powering through the USC offensive line to end the half pic.twitter.com/1IhLDneZH9— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 28, 2026

Nnodim registered five quarterback hits and a sack last season, but the redshirt sophomore could continue to develop as a rusher at Penn State.

Utah transfer DT Dallas Vakalahi didn’t register a sack in 2025, but was able to get two the season before pic.twitter.com/5rzlCFY7r2— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 28, 2026

It’s clear most of the new additions weren’t brought to Happy Valley to rush the passer, though, so with the exception of McPherson, their snap counts on pass downs could be limited.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State notebook | Mike Rhoades talks support from administration, insight from Ohio State loss
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
After a ninth straight conference loss for Penn State, Mike Rhoades was back in the Bryce Jordan Center media room for his weekly presser Tuesday afternoon.

Rhoades spoke on the support he gets from Penn State’s administration in addition to some insight into the defeat to Ohio State on Monday night.

Here’s more of what Rhoades said.

Support from administration

Rhoades is in Year 3 of his attempt to build a basketball program at Penn State. There hasn’t been much historical success by the Nittany Lions, with Rhoades often referring that the team has only seen “pockets of success.”

Rhoades was asked if Penn State’s administration is giving enough support to help him get the program to where he wants it to be.

“That's the envelope I got to push all the time, and we're going to fight for that,” Rhoades said. “That's what's great about working for (Vice President for Intercollegiate Athletics) Pat Kraft is I can have those open conversations with him about where we need to go and where we need to push … I could walk into Pat's office at any time and sit down and have a kind of candid conversation with him because we all want the same thing. We want to build this program to make it a winner.”

The Nittany Lions are off to a 9-11 start this season, including an 0-9 start to Big Ten play. Last year saw Rhoades’ squad finish 16-15 with six Big Ten wins, which was after a 16-17 record with nine conference regular-season wins during Rhoades’ first campaign with the team in 2023-24.

This season, Penn State has the youngest roster in the Big Ten and one of the youngest in the country, according to Rhoades. The Nittany Lions have gone up against more experienced teams across the Big Ten so far through the conference slate.

“The culture of college basketball now is to get to get older quicker, and to get bigger and stronger and older quicker, and our league is doing that in a specific way,” Rhoades said. “That's something we got to address as we move forward. But that's what's great about Pat is it's not a ‘No.’ It's ‘Alright, let's see what we can do,’ and we have some great conversations about it.”

What went wrong vs. Ohio State

Midway through the first half of Monday’s game, Ohio State went on a 14-2 run to give it a 25-11 advantage over Penn State. The Nittany Lions cut the lead down to 33-23 with 3:55 left in the half, but the Buckeyes managed to gain a 50-32 halftime advantage.

Ohio State shot 66.7% from the field and 54.5% from 3-point range during the first half.

“We're just not a very good defensive team,” Rhoades said. “In league play, other teams are shooting 52% (from the field) and 41% from three. That's not winning basketball. That's hard. I do think some of this is youth, some of it is guarding star players who are really good players. We're getting beat, we're getting beat way too much, and then they get going. And we've really struggled letting good players get going.”

Penn State prevented Ohio State guard Bruce Thornton from generating much as he ended with nine points on 4-of-6 shooting. However, as Rhoades noted, fellow guard John Mobley Jr. went off instead for 25 points with 5-of-11 shooting from 3-point range.

It was the third consecutive game where the Nittany Lions held a large halftime deficit. Penn State slimmed Ohio State’s lead down to 60-59 in the second half, but it never fully overcame the 18-point hole at halftime as the Buckeyes won, 84-78.

“I think our defense, our guarding, and the half-court defense, we struggled, just not consistent. I think that's number one. The second thing, and very close to the number one, is when another team goes on a run, instead of having poise, and it starts with me helping these guys understand it, it’s, ‘I got hit a three. I got to make a play to get us back in it.’ And that makes it a snowball, and it's become a big snowball in some of these games.”

Players’ minutes in Ohio State game

There were a few lineup choices that stood out during the Ohio State game, such as guard Melih Tunca getting 17 minutes and forward Mason Blackwood only getting four minutes.

Tunca played just 16 minutes during the Maryland and Wisconsin games combined, and he has to be more aggressive to see more action, according to Rhoades. Against the Buckeyes, Rhoades said Tunca showcased that, and the Turkey native notched 13 points on 4-of-8 shooting from the field.

“I thought what was promising for Melih yesterday was how hard he tried to play defense and he battled,” Rhoades said. “Then if you get lost in the game of effort and approach and just being aggressive and flying around, usually your instincts take over. And you saw his instincts on the offensive end take over. We need that. We need that from him.”

Elsewhere, Blackwood saw limited action despite coming off a career night against Wisconsin, which saw him tally 14 points and six rebounds.

Rhoades cited gameflow for the reasoning behind Blackwood’s lesser minutes, with wing Eli Rice totaling a career-high 20 points on 6-of-11 3-point shooting in 34 minutes and forward Josh Reed getting 13 points and five rebounds in 38 minutes.

“Mason's had some great games for us, and the way the game was going yesterday, I thought Josh was playing really well, and Eli was shooting the ball well,” Rhoades said. “Some of it is, I didn't want to have three or four freshmen on the court at the same time. I mean, Mason has improved tremendously, and he's getting better and better. Some games he's going to play more than others.”

Also in the frontcourt, big men Saša Ciani and Justin Houser saw one minute each versus the Buckeyes. Rhoades said Houser has done a “really good job” of “picking things up,” but the speed of the game is what’s catching up to him.

“We're going to go with the guys that can help us in that moment,” Rhoades said. “Some matchups are better than others, and (we) try to put them out there for them to have a chance with the right guys to have success.”
